content:
r 15, 2016
												There are a ton of MMORPGs out there.  I admit, I got into this one after it went Free to Play.  Well... what sucked me in for 4000+hours, was the fact that you can earn in the game, the same points you need to purchase with cash money, in order to get the expansion packs.  So... even though you can purchase your way up the levels faster, by spending money on the quest packs that pay off in XPs and level development, you can also grind your way to those same level packs.Meaning, it truly *is* Free to Play.There are benefits to making a single cash purchase of some Turbine points... it changes your status permanently up one notch... this gives you an additional character slot.  LOTRO actually encourages the creation of a character created soley for the purpose of grinding the early Turbine Points that are far easier to get (deeds where you have to kill 45 enemies to earn points... as opposed to the deeds not that much further on in the "pay" areas where you have to kill 150... or 450 to earn the same number of Turbine Points).  You create a character, run through those deeds... hopefully with a friend or two... and delete that chacter.  Then... make another.  It is a great use for the third slot... until you earn enough Turbine Points to purchase another slot.That, and you get to try different characters and builds.The crafting is very detailed.  You will be creating characters that are good at one thing.  It is even possible to have a character that you don't actually know how to play well... but that you have levelled to great heights only through crafting.  You can also increase a character's crafting skill far beyond their capacity to survive in the areas where they would need to gather the raw materials they need.  This makes the in-game player store system... the auction house... much more of an integral part of the game.  That.. or you use your second character to go out and gather materials, and then store them in your shared bank... or your house storage.The fact that it is set in the Tolkien Universe is a huge bonus.  Everyone should play a hobbit once.Maps are large.... and the scenery is great.  It is fun to ride around when you are high enough level not to attract mobs.  Many players go into the game, to spend time in Bree and hang out with friends.Add it.  Play it.  Costs nothing but time.  Definitely worth more than that.

number of helpful: 41 of 42 people (98%) found this review helpful
content:
1
												Since my gametime (off Steam hitting around 10k) is ridiculously high i figured i'd give an in-depth review of the game both on a leveling and end game basis for both new players and potential returning players as well. This review will be done on a positive/indifferent/negative basis.Positives: + Class variation and static roles: . You play as a Minstrel, you'll be healing. You play as a Guardian, you'll be tanking etc. Some classes such as Beornings and RKs can do multiple jobs, but the game follows the old school MMO system (as expected given its age). Over 9 classes to choose from all with unique roles both end game and unique abilities and playstyles while leveing and questing.+ Graphics:     The game graphically has aged like fine wine and is still appealing to the eye, especially in the more recently released zones. The revamped zones in low level areas and the new regions in Gondor are more up to date and places such as North Ithilien are breahtaking. The artstyle that LOTRO offers fits the game perfectly. + The Main Story:   The overarching plot is fantastic at least in Volume 1 + 4, with Volume 2 being good and Volume 3 being 'okay'.  There are currently 4 volumes (the latter still underway). + Music/OST:     This has always been top notch and they've done a great job, especially in places such as Moria, Angmar, Rohan & Gondor to truly capture Tolkiens works in the flesh through the music that is played while venturing around.+ The Lore:    This is without doubt the closest to the literature source you can find in game or video form. Fantastic job in sticking and expanding upon Tolkiens works. + F2P:   I could go on about this for hours but looking at it from the perspective of a new player, and the ability to buy the content with in-game currency and not pay a single penny (Unless you want to PvP) is pretty astounding. Naturally it's grindy as hell but it's free, so you can't really complain. + Raiding:  At the time of this review there is plenty of end game content to keep you busy, some more difficult than others that require a kinship (Guild), voice communication as well as understanding the instance and your class respectively. + Landscapes/Open World: This speaks for itself. LOTRO is huge, and the atmosphere and immersion in some locations is phenomonal. Places such as Moria, Lothlorien, Minas Tirith, Mirkwood etc really stand out as the pinnacle of world building in this game.Indifferent Points:=Optimization: Game crashes are a thing as is lag, especially in highly populated zones. Can be game/immersion breaking.= PvMP:   PvMP (Player vs Monster Player) has so many positives but also a few negatives (as well as lack of any development pretty much since its release from the Developers in 10 years except for attempted balances between classes). The skill level for PvP is insane and that makes it both fun and enjoyable. If you enjoy a challenge PvP is definetly the hardest part of the game to play well. There are plenty of great and friendly players in PvP on both sides, but also a very negative and childish community that ruins it which can potentially  make you lose interest if you don't learn to ignore the chat. That's PvP for you. There are, as in many MMOs 'flavour of the month classes' that are OP with updates, the only issue is that given how small Standing Stones team are and the lack of monthly updates (Updates are released less frequently than in bigger MMOs such as ESO, FFXIV, WoW etc) it's an on going dilemma. = Developer Interaction:   This isn't really a positive or negative but in comparison to how the game used to be (under Codemasters in Europe) when developers and GameMasters used to interact with the community very frequently, the lack of actual interaction between players and the Dev Team (outside of the Community Manager through Twitch & Forums) leaves room for improvement and more engagement. Despite this in recent months this has improved slightly, so hopefully we'll see more involvement from the team with in-game events in the future.= Roleplaying:     I'm not someone who roleplays in LOTRO so i can't offer much feedback on this. The community is, for the most part really friendly and welcoming and there are servers specifically for Roleplaying, so it must be good!.=Crafting:     Crafting is something, in most MMOs (with the exception of ESO) that i've never really enjoyed. I don't mind crafting in LOTRO when i need too but i don't take any particular pleasure in doing it.. If you enjoy crafting in other MMOs you'l likely enjoy it in this game as it has many viable purposes (from leveling gear, to consumables to end game relics). It's also part of questing as many of the crafing items you need can be found while playing and leveling through the game in each area. I'd stick this as a positive except it honestly isn't anything overly special that stands out. It's just 'there'.Negatives: - End Game Grind:     While people seem to enjoy leveling alts (and while you can skip it with Valar upgrades to boost your character, bearing in mind you'll have to go back and do your deeds and learn your class anyway so it's pointless) you will pretty much have to go through the exact same content again from 1-105. While you can level in certain different areas for some levels you will have to venture through Moria, Rohan, Gondor on multiple toons. The issue isn't so much leveling (which is fun) but the grind you need to achieve a playable character for end game content. I could write an entire paragraph detailing how bad grinding to be 'raid ready' is (in an effort by Devs to keep people in game between major updates i assume) if people want an overview, but in a nutshell you have to; Obtain 83 Class Points, Get around 10+ Virtue Traits to level 20 Each. You'll have to level, upgrade, reequip and grind items for your legendary weapons. You'll have to grind essences and then craft them by obtaining crafting items from many different sources through grinding them to get the required essences you want, and even then you aren't guaranteed the best essences. ^ If Standing Stones made this less grindy (especially the essence and legendary item grind) for ALT characters, it would make the end game grind more approachable for people to do it more than once without making it feel like a chore. - Class Development:   In a nutshell; Beornings were released and are a broken mess and have been with only one patch since they were released. An introduction to a new race/class and little changes shows a lack of care, at least in my eyes for the finished product or player feedback. I haven't seen a new skill (or ability) on my main class in years. What happened?! Further more there are now MANY useless skills on multiple classes that haven't been made viable or addressed in years. This also goes for legendary legacies on legendary weapons. An example on Loremaster (My Main) is; Gust of Wind on Loremaster. Completely pointless. Ents go to War is no longer as viable as it used to be and Natures Fury is pretty much pointless as well in class rotations except for its pretty animations. - Side Quests/Missions:     This is more nitpicking but the sidequests in LOTRO (There are exceptions) are.....typical MMO fetch or kill quests. While some of the side quests have interesting stories and background with the lore, nothing has ever really stood out when questing in LOTRO outside of the Main Quest and stories. The actual stories that go along with the quests have improved considerablly since release, so perhaps i'm being abit harsh here. Despite this if you've played through Minas Tirth and done the questchain there, you'll know where i'm coming from when i say it's far from enjoyable at times. It has its ups and downs..- Mounted Combat:   Speaks for itself. It wasn't asked for and hasn't been used since Rohan effectively or at all outside of a couple of scenarios. End: Recommended :)! Thanks for reading

												I will start off with a few good points as to why i would recommend this game (Only slightly) to people who enjoy mmos with a already created universe. The game does a pretty good job at recreating  the lotr universe of Middle-Earth or at least it did at one point. For you see it would seem the worlds are almost empty, If you are thinking of just playing cusually then get ready to grind like hell to get the turpine points to buy most of the items you need in-game. For example you need turpine points to buy the riding skill early game and alot of the other good cosmetic items, but dont get me wrong i like how you can actually get the coins with out having to pay real money it will just take a long time to get them. With the Semi pay-to-win out of the way there is the problem of the servers drying up, beacuse if you are wanting to get into this game now unless you are starting with someone get ready to walk the halls alone. There are a good amount of pros and cons to cover aslso-Pros-well crafted maps-decent gaming community-not entirely pay-to-win-story with an interesting twist-crafting is rather good-Cons-close to empty servers-lots of grinding for "turbine points"-some glitches (though what games don't)-armour doesn't have the greatest apeal in the looksThe lists can go on for both but that is always up to the indivual person, because i have found you can't always go off of reviews you have to figure out if you like the game yourself. That being said i wrote this just to educate the people who might want to start playing this game and hopefully turbine might see this and lay off the pay-to-win a little but. So all in all it is rather fun, i guess i might have something to do with my love for Lotr.<Just clearing up i have played this game for humdreds of hours outside of steam>

content:
er 5, 2016
												I've been wanting to write a review for LotRO for a long time, but every time I attempt it, I find that I cannot do the game justice. Nonetheless, I love it enough that I owe it one.I have played LotRO since 2007, and save a few hiatuses, I still play to this day. With that much history, I am sorely tempted to go into a long-winded tirade about all of my experiences with this game, how I feel about all of the changes it has endured, and share my thoughts about how it ended up where it is today. It is difficult at times to get across your point and enthuisasm without including the aforementioned. However, as this is meant to be a review and not a novel, I will attempt to refrain from that and keep my focus on the point. LotRO is a very story-based and driven game, as you might expect from an MMO derived from Tolkien's works. While it does have the common fetch-and-kill quests and sometimes redundant feeling tasks that you'll find in every MMO, by and large the quests are compelling and fulfilling. This is especially true of the Epic quests, which deal with the members of the Fellowship of the Ring and their actions. The world is expansive and highly immersive, and there is adventure to be had everywhere, in many different forms. With a few exceptions, the development team is incredibly loyal to and respective of Tolkien's writings and based the landscape and heart of Middle Earth off of the books, not the Peter Jackson movies. You will not find another game, anywhere, that has as much love for Tolkien’s works as the Lord of the Rings Online. It felt warm and grand when I first started, and it still does today.That being said, LotRO has been around for a very long time. It has numerous bugs and suffers from issues you might expect from a game of its age. Speaking strictly in terms of MMOs, it does not have the end game content or high numbers of raids that you might be looking for or expect. It is limited in what it can implement for mechanics and flashy gameplay; It runs on an engine built in 2002, originally used on Asheron's Call 2. It has numerous bugs and flaws that continue to harry it despite attempted fixes and updates. Those who feel so inclined can purchase many perks and advantages through the in-game store, which is obnoxious in its attempts to get you to notice and use it. Its population has waned in recent years, as have the resources devoted to it. Likewise, its focus on group play has lessened. Essentially, if you are looking for the more common focuses of MMOs these days, meaning lots of raiding, end game and group content, PvP, top of the line graphics, flashy gameplay, etc, you will not find that here in levels that will satisfy you.Nonetheless, the game looks impressive - running it on high graphics, it hides its age extremely well. The community remains one of the friendliest and most helpful to be found in MMOs, and whether you enjoy RP or not, there are plenty of tools and resources available to cater to both casual and extreme role-players. There exists plenty of humor and easter eggs hidden around for casual players or huge Tolkien nerds to find. To steal a quote from a blog I read recently, "It has a heart and soul that very few games can boast of having, and those looking only at the graphics, technicalities and the gameplay to judge an MMO won’t be able to appreciate its true worth, ever. LotRO is not a trendy game, possibly never will be, and it’s most likely better for it. .... we fans get to have a game that is worthy of Tolkien’s work, despite any and all flaws." And there you have it. If you're looking for story and exploration, love Tolkien's works, or want a friendly and reasonably casual MMO to tinker around with, LotRO is an amazing choice. Despite all of its flaws, it is a gem amongst games, and is the most faithful and successful attempt at visualizing Tolkien's world. I have, would, and will strongly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of Tolkien in any way.

												The number of hours that I have played this game through steam does not even come close to the actual number of hours played as I've also played this game through turbine's own launcher.This is the one MMO which I always come back to. Over the years I've taken a few breaks from the game but I always crawl my way back, and am welcomed back with open arms. The game is showing signs of age and graphically it can struggle, especially in the newer areas (Minas Tirith for example) but throughout this I still come back and love this game with all my heart.I have recently completed the epic quest line where the riders of rohan comes to the aid of Gondor, riding through the pelennor fields - Riding side by side with Theoden and his riders - OMG my heart was in my mouth for the entire instance and I only wished it had lasted for longer.I originally started on Withywindle and with the recent server merges have moved to Evernight. Everyone will have something different that draws them to Lotro but for me it has always been the social aspect. Finding the right kinship for me changed this game to something that I look forward to playing. This is a game that if you put the time and effort into can be completely F2P - There are plenty of TP farming guides around and if you have the patience to grind you can buy almost everything from the store. Saying that I would recommend going VIP at least once within the game. There are a few perks that are unlocked (swift travel for example) that you cannot purchase through the store, and the amount of love and time turbine put into the gameplay and story it is worth giving a little back to them - They can get a lot of negativity but if not for them then I would not have this game that I so love to play.

ber 25, 2014
												As a veteran of MMOs (and MUDs before that) I would have to recommend this game for several reason.-F2P: Its actually free to play. The RMT (real money trade) store items are mostly cosmetic. There are some that effect gameplay convenience wise. However, the RMT currency (Turbine Points) can be also earned in game in many different ways. Basically, the game gives you RMT currency as a side result of playing.-The Community. The community is not the typical MMO trollfest. MOST players you come across are more than willing to lend a hand, give advice or even (sometimes) free items etc. They are very friendly and generally tend to help the new players out.-Social MMO. Despite this game having boatloads of grindy combat like any other MMO, there are many  unique social aspects to this game. Making/playing your own musical instruments in a band, player/guild housing etc.-Massive world. The gameworld in this is rather big. While certain areas are locked out until you purchase the expansion, there are equivalent zones for the free (budget) player.-Customer Support is very ... human. And tends to be helpful with the player rather than absolute sticklers to policy.-Mounted Combat/Legendary Weapons/Raids/Dungeons/Crafting/Typical MMO stuff etc., etc.,CONS:-I had performance issues on my budget laptop. The game can get very laggy with xpacs and infusion of players.-WoW ruined any mmo without flying mounts ><TL:DR give it a spin if you like mmos. While it doesn't break any new ground in the genre it is a solid game with unique social aspects.

												LOTRO is a wonderful MMO by any standards, but to fans of Tolkien's works it achieves something far greater than any other game. A huge recreation of Middle-Earth, with a lot of it's characters and plentiful lore to be found amongst the beautiful scenarios. number of helpful: 29 of 33 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2013
												The Lord of the Rings Online bears the name of one of the most famous books in the English language. If you are a fan of the aforementioned books then LotRO has a lot to offer you. It's rich in material from the books, and despite its age still offers a detailed and beautiful rendering of Middle-Earth.If you are a fan of MMO's then LotRO is probably not the best bet. It is lacking in PvP (only one region allows for PvP, The Ettenmoors) instead opting to focus upon co-operative play and PvE. At the present point it is difficult finding beginning region play, with most activity occuring at current end-game level. This makes the beginning game play tiers somewhat lonely and more akin to a generic offline RPG than an actual MMO, just another reason why those wanting a true MMO experience will probably be put off.Another criticism (as with many free to play structured games) is the increasing reliance on Pay to Win structures in order to make money. This has somewhat unblanced the game and makes it especially difficult at lower tiers. The ability to buy most weapon enhancements and skill increases means those who pay will quickly outstrip those who do not.That said the community is wonderful. By and large most of the players are helpful and happy to proved assistance in various forms, with a level of maturity that is fairly uncommon to MMO's. It is also a fairly active community, it may not boast huge subscriber and player numbers but the players by and large are people who play regularly and consistently. In terms of roleplaying the RP servers are quite active, and regular events are held and arranged by players, yet further evidence of why the player community is one of the friendliest and active around.On the whole I would definitely recommend LotRO especially to those who are fans of the world, as it provides an extended experience of the literature. It is by no means a perfect game, and it is fairly old now. but seeing as it has lasted so long, is testament to not only the love of Tolkien's works but also to the dedication of its player base.

number of helpful: 121 of 190 people (64%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
ber 24, 2014
												I’m playing with an increasingly miserable lvl 58 elf huntress. She wants to see all of Middle Earth, but she won’t. Because I am broke.I feel like writing this review in caps lock and yelling at the top of my lungs “pay to win pay to win pay to win”. Middle Earth is beautiful. Beginnings are sweet as you’re not engaged in battles straight away. You start in Eriador, and exact place depends on which race you chose to play with. Crafting is soothing, exploring is fun, everything looks amazing. When you get a horse, things get a lot easier and you find yourself immersed into the world and enjoying it so much. It leaves you curious for other parts of Middle Earth and you want to level up to enjoy them all. Music is great too and fits every scenery beautifully.But then, around levels 20-30 you realize you need to purchase a quest pack to play the next area on the map. That's fine, so you do that, still being into the game. Then you grind grind grind, until you face the same thing again. So you buy another area. And so on. Thing is, I didn’t even mind purchasing packs to see more. What I really did mind though, is how boring and repetitive quests became while levelling in parallel became increasingly harder and frustrating. I'm starting to think the best way to play this game is getting a horse and just riding like there's no tomorrow until you reach Mordor. Noro lim Asfaloth, noro lim!Unless on top of all those purchases you want to buy experience tomes. Thanks Turbine, but no thanks.Community used to be better too, but I’m guessing a lot of people left for which I can’t really blame them. Also in walks my biggest regret, and that’s starting my toon on a non RP server which is extremely boring and has very little activity. However, if you do the same mistake and want to try another server with the same toon, Turbine offers you to transfer it for 20 €. What a surprise, I think I'll get a heart attack.  Still, there were times when I was so desperate I was willing to put all that aside and give it another shot. Then server started crashing. Guess it’s not meant to be, Lotro.

number of helpful: 29 of 35 people (83%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												     Traversing Middle-Earth slaying orcs and fighting alongside heroes like Legolas, Halbarad, and even Prince Theodred; what more could you ask for? Honestly, this game is not what it once was; that does not mean I don't recommend it. The Lord of the Rings Online is truly a masterpiece made a very passionate team. My first few years in this game were phenomenal - Don't let my Steam numbers fool you - if anything this game has given me a much deeper love for the lore. It's a game where the little things are the best things. The Yule (December) festival is by far the best festival I have participated in in any of the MMOs I have ever played. However instead of going on and on about this game, here are some pros and cons:Pros:- Middle-Earth is huge. Turbine has covered The Shire, to Bree, from Forochel to Mirkwood, Moria, Rohan, Ered Luin, Rivendell, and everywhere in between.- Very lore-friendly. Turbine has created an almost seamless integration of your character into the lore, the events that transpire through the main story (epics) fit together wonderfully with the lore.- Meet and fight alongside mighty heroes. You will get the chance to meet and fight alongside members of the fellowship. Not only that, but you will also meet people such as Halbarad, Elrond, Galadriel and Celeborn, King Theoden, Radagast and Bilbo Baggins; the list goes on.- Witness major events in the story. This includes the Breaking of the Fellowship, the fall of Boromir, - which is waaaay better than the movies -  The Battle for Helms Deep, the final stand of Prince Theodred, the forming of the Gray Company, and many more events, which Minas Tirith and the Battle for Pelennor Fields on the way later this year.- The crafting system. The crafting system is by far one of the best I have experienced in an MMO.- Legendary weapons. You will be able to obtain powerful legendary weapons that grow in power as they are used; you can even name them!- The outfit system. By far the best outfit system I have ever witnessed in an MMO. With the purchase of a wardrobe, you can cosmetically wear ANY piece of armor/clothing in the game regardless of class or race.- The deeding system. The deeds while 'grindy' award Turbine Points (TP) which can be used to purchase quest packs, cosmetics, and other things from the LOTRO store (See Below)There are no doubt a few I missed, but these are the highlights for me. Now onto the cons:- It is impossible to advance in the game without spending money (unless you grind a LOT). I was able to make it to level 52 without spending a dime, and having no quest packs for levels 30+ Levels 1-30 are free, however 30-100 (yes level 100) all require the purchase of quest packs and expansion packs either with real money or Turbine Points.- The game is not what it once was. While still enjoyable, the game has just started to really lose it's spark. I truly feel sorry for those who did not get to experience the game before 2012. It was amazing back then. But with all the gameplay/mechanic/etc. changes it has ruined the experience for me and many veteran players.- While nice for new players, the game is not very veteran friendly. I covered this more or less in the above statement. With all the changes going on many of the veteran players have left the game. I have seen lots of new players joining, and the game is definitely new player friendly, but at a terrible cost.- Lots of the servers are dead (or dying). Brandywine is the server to choose. It is one of the most populated servers and one of the few very populated ones still in game. That's not to say that LOTRO has a tiny playerbase; most people are just on a few servers like Brandywine.I hope I have been able to sum up this game in a positive way with the 5 years of experience I have with it. I truly recommend giving LOTRO a try. ESPECIALLY if you love the lore; that's one of the things that keeps me in the game. With this in mind, I will mention that Lord of the Rings is nearing it's end. I do not believe Turbine will renew their license past 2017. We will luckily get Mordor, and from the looks of it, the Grey Havens and the areas that are needed to "Complete" the game. If you're on the fence about this game, I suggest you get it while you can; it is free after all.

content:
4, 2016
												Terrible, even infuriating, customer service. Despite this being a prime example of a good solid classic MMORPG.Had a bad experience with a GM a couple years ago, arbitrarily changed my name from "Theodophilus" to some randomly generated name. Claimed it broke the rules and was too religious, despite Theod- being a very common name prefix in the LOTR universe. I questioned him about it, he refused to change it back, and even banned my account for three days because I pressed the issue. There is no recourse at all as a customer, WB is just too big to care, and Turbine (or whoever) have no real means set up of dealing with these problems, they had a suggestion box and ticket system, true, but it's /dev/null, never got so much as a form letter response from those venues. Once a year I call up WB and asked if they've changed the name back for free, or taken any action to rectify or make amends for my terrible customer service experience. They sympathetically tell me nothing can be done on the phone, and I tell them that I enjoyed the game itself and would have possibly been spending money on it, and they have now lost $X amount more dollars in the past year I may have spent, because at the time of the occurrence I happily a subscriber--This was after the game went f2p, I figured I liked it, I spent time on it, I would support it.The GMs have no oversight, and can pretty much do whatever they want without repercussions. If you do gamble on this game, I would encourage you to spend no money on it, so the only thing you will lose if you encounter a rogue GM is your time. GM abuse shatters the illusion within an MMO that what you do within it has any meaning or permanency whatsoever, someone can just come along and spitefully fiddle with your entry in the database, what's the point? The suspension of disbelief was shattered, and this was reinforced by the abject lack of customer care or public relations. While the game is a fine example of a classic MMORPG, unfortunately so is the customer service, from a bygone era when gaming was a less competitive market, a higher ratio of gamers were children, and the novelty of being in an MMORPG at all may have been enough to get some kid to tolerate the unpoliced abuse by a GM. This isn't the past, I'm not a kid, and they have lost a lot of money from me. Always vote with your wallet, it's one of the few things that really matter in this world, unfortunately.Nothing preciousssSSssss here, just a database some guy can drunk dial on a whim.

er 2, 2016
												awesome game. this is pretty much only mmo that i've ever played for a longer period of time. it is obviously very story driven game. you follow the lord of the rings story by completing epic quest line. and this epic quest/story line really is awesome, it takes you through whole middle earth, you meet tons of characters, you participate in a lot of instances and explore every region of middle earth. it really makes you feel like you're part of the story. besides this, there are loads of regular side quests, and if you take your time like me, and read text about each quest, game becomes much more immersive.the middle earth is huge and diverse. you have nice looking shire (green, flowers, friendly people), then you have arctic cold and frozen forochel; barren, dark and hostile angmar. 10/10 for world (middle earth) variety.you have 5 races and 10 classes to choose from. nothing too crazy, but definitely not bad. each race has it's own starter zone and unique quests, where you learn a bit about lore, and meet some characters important for that race.there's quite a bit of instances, raids and skirmishes to choose from, and most of them can scale to your level.game has couple of regions where you can purchase your own house and decorate it with trophies from battles.community is friendly and mature.f2p model: you can play whole game without spending a cent, and i know people that have done that, but it requires a lot of grind. personally, i bought eriador quest pack, and all expansions (you can get them for free if you grind enough).game is not perfect though. it has performance issues in newer areas where your fps is constantly low. i don't know if there is fix for this, but i haven't looked for it really. another downside for me is that all weapons within same class (axes, swords, spears etc...) look pretty similar. i'd like to see more variety there. mobs can get a bit boring, and basically after you've seen mobs on first 30-40 levels (maybe even before) you've seen them all. they definitely need more variety.there's quite a bit of things i didn't go through (crafting, exploring, hobbies, mounts...) but it would take forever to write this review...8.5/10

number of helpful: 22 of 24 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 18, 2016
												  As a big fan of Lord of the Rings, i decided to play the MMO game version of it when I first came across with back in the summer of 2011.During my journeys throughout Middle-Earth I have met important personalities, visited many places and helped a lot of kind people. And I have enjoyed every minute of my adventure..  First of all, I have to congratulate the developers of Turbine for their effort in the creation of Middle-Earth. Following Tolkien's masterworks and using a little bit of their imagination, they created a world which is astonishing and different from any other game worlds. From the green plains of Shire to the icy peaks of Misty Mountains with the deep mines of Moria below them and even beyond, to the White City of Minas Tirith, capital of Gondor, each region offers a unique experience for the player. However the graphics are indeed a bit outdated and it might frustrate some people but that doesn't stop you from enjoying the graphical scenery of the game.  Another good thing about this game is it's variety of quests and tasks. I remember when i was fighting a Barlog in Angmar and the next moment I was at Shire, fishing at Brandywine to collect some fishes for a hobbit. Because adventure in games is not always about fighting epic monsters and bosses...Needless to say that your own personal story is so well merged in the story of the Fellowship of the Ring both chronically and aesthetically. I have to say that is a smart move from the developers that you are not declared as the chosen one or the savior of Middle-Earth from the very beginning. You are just one of the many folks out there who is eager for some adventure and wants to pursue his/her destiny ...Gradually you gain fame from your deeds and more and more people are pinning their hopes on you to purge Middle-Earth from evil.  LOTRO'S music and soundtracks is a strong feature of this game. There's a wide variety of songs here which elevate your gaming experience. Each region has their respective soundtracks which make the game even more atmospheric. You have to test it for yourself to see what I am talking about.  The overall gameplay experience is good. Crafting is an essential and rewarding part of the game. The combat system is enjoyable. You have a large amount of abilities with a variety of combos. LOTRO is by 99% a PvE game because is focusing on its story rather than the fighting. We all know what happens in the end. Good guys win, bad guys lose. Although the PvMP system , where you are playing as an servant or Sauron, is rather fascinating. The community is friendly and there are lots of players willing to participate in numerous instances. Furthermore, the deed system ( =achievements) rewards you with Turbine Points and other stuff ( points for buying things in store) if you are exploring the regions or killing more enemies.  Well, Turbine may be a little expensive ( don't let it mislead you with the F2P label) but in my opinion the pay system is quite handy. Apart from the subscription system where you are forced to pay once a month to have all the areas for free ( like in WoW), you can buy each region of Middle Earth from the store for an amount of money and then you can have it forever with all the quests and deeds of this area.  Personally, I was addicted to this game since the beginning. It is a very good MMORPG for all the LOTR-fans out there who have watched the films or read the books. But if you are not one of them, why don’t give it a try and join in an adventure throughout Middle-Earth?

number of helpful: 28 of 35 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												I rarely play MMOs anymore, so I will avoid talking about combat and such in this review. Instead, I will focus on other elements of the game.So, congrats: you've just found the portal to Middle-earth. LOTRO does a wonderful job recreating the world. Despite the graphics, I still had loads of fun exploring whenever I wasn't off killing orcs. Some places, like Lothlorien, are gorgeous and breathtaking. Others, like Angmar, manage to get under your skin and make you feel just a tiny bit repulsed. The atmospheres of each region are wonderfully conveyed.Tolkien gave us a fleshed-out world, and instead of drastically changing the lore, LOTRO adds onto it. Granted, the LOTRO-created lore is plausible within Middle-earth, so I'm usually content to let it slide. As an added plus, a lot of it is interesting!I haven't been able to get far into the main storyline (nearly through with Volume 2), but I can vouch that it's engaging. While the Fellowship is off doing their own thing, your character is tasked with helping the Free Peoples of Middle-earth. Side quests are the usual fetch/kill quests, so nothing really notable there. You can choose to run around in groups of people (appropriately named "fellowships") or just go solo.And that leads to what I reckon is my only complaint. It's not really a free game. You have to buy quest packs for some regions, so it's a lot harder to level up quickly when you've run out of things to do solo and don't have money to spend. That's how I got bored.Servers are usually populated with a fair amount of people, with most hanging out on the roleplaying servers. Something that made LOTRO really stand out for me was the kind community. I've met a large variety of players ranging from high schoolers to parents. Many offered to help me out whenever I needed it. There will be the rare troll in the chat, but you can simply ignore them. Everyone's there to have fun and nerd out over Tolkien's works.If you're a major fan of Middle-earth and don't mind some tweaks here and there, I recommend this game. 7/10.

content:
ry 23, 2016
												Wow. It is really hard to review a game which became a part of your life and of your soul. I'll start with negative points then, hope it will be easier for us all this way.1. Move along if you're not familiar with Lord of the Rings. This game is made for fans of Middle-Earth by fans of Middle-Earth. It is story-driven game which rewards you for being into this world. It is not worth your time nor money if you are indifferent about LotR. Better go read some books. You might as well close this review, won't be anything more useful here for you.2. Teh graphics suxx. LotRO doesn't hold its line against any of nowadays-popular MMORPGs (except maybe WoW, which looks just as awful now). I'm not sure if I placed 2 first points in the right order, but anyway: if you're looking for impressive effects and fappable grills, move along. Go play TERA, it's just what you need (and quite good a MMORPG by the way).3. The combat system is decades since deprecated. Yes, it's THAT point-and-click we all were tired of for years. If you consider it disgusting and still reading it for some reason - move along. Go play TERA or anything else, there is a plenty of action MMORPGs nowadays.4. The game is not free. Period. If you don't spend a single penny on the game, you will have really hard time past level 25. However, don't leave yet. It's the first matter I'll deal with below.That's it for contras, I think. As promised, concerning money. You have two options: to buy a subscription or to purchase all items (mostly, quest packs) separately. Aside from that, you'll need two out of three DLCs ("Steely Dawn" is auxiliary, nothing mandatory there). Taking all the discounts into concern (~20% off in-game items, 50-75% off DLCs at large Steam sales), the second option is much more convenient. Still, it will cost you dearly (around $30 for Russian players and probably twice that much for all the others: there's a solid reason for this difference, but I won't elaborate here).Still reading this? Kudos to you then. Now I'm going to persuade you to install LotRO.1. THE STORY. I cannot stress this enough. The game is highly story-driven. Every single quest is a brick in a huge building of the Middle-Earth story. The epic storyline follows the road of the Fellowship of the Ring. It reached Gondor as of when I'm writing this. And it's called epic for a good reason. Still, side quests play no lesser role. All of them contribute to the story and to the atmosphere.2.  The graphics. You've got it right, and f**k those who left in the progress. The effects might seem simple, the grills might seem not fappable enough, but it's LotR, not a manga. It feels natural, however natural it might be for a fantasy world. And you have my word that you will stop once in a while just to have a longer look at that landscape.3. The world. Do you remember? It's the good old Middle-Earth. You can venture into icy crevasses of Forochel (don't jump in the water!), walk among the golden mallorns of Lothlorien, explore the dangerous depths of Moria and ride with rohirrim against the tide of Uruk-hai. You can even find a hat Gandalf dropped at the very bottom of the Endless Stair.4. The atmosphere. You get used to it, to every good and bad thing about the game, and you really feel like you live in this world. The domestical system. The music. The language in quests is good and proper English (or Elven, mind you). The mobs are not concentrated at farming spots, but are mixed and scattered across vast logical regions. The crafting system (you can actually cook, Valar be damned!) HP is called Morale, so you don't actually die, but desperately flee when severely outmatched. The Dread system which turns your screen gray and replaces minimap with a flaming eye, when you encounter something truly fearsome. Like a Balrog corpse. It is, definitely, the best LotR-inspired game in terms of atmosphere that ever existed.I could go on. I could mention the community, the music playing (yep, you can play any music in the game at a MIDI quality), the PK absence, the epic battles and whatnot. But I will conclude.Come and feel it yourself. If you're still here - it is worth it. This is an experience you'll never regret. And LotRO will love you back.THIS GAME IS A F***ING BLAST AND I LOVE IT. DO IT. Join the Fellowship.Oh Eru, I wanted to say it from the very start.Sincerely Yours,Talcano Mithrenhen, Landroval (ex-Mirkwood).

												I played this game from open beta and loved it. After Mirkwood came out a few things in my life had me put LotRO on hold.  I came back about 2 months ago and it feels like a different game. That being said, it's not a bad thing, just different from what I remember. Not dramatically different but enough to make it interesting. It is still one of the best MMOs I've ever played (going all the way back to Ultima Online before EA or whoever got a hold of it and ♥♥♥♥ed it all up). The game follows the books pretty closely (and not the movies). So if you like Tolkien and are looking to get into a MMO, this is the right place for you. Even if you haven't read the books and just seen the Hobbit and Rings trilogies, there is enought in the game for you to say, "Ah, I remember that!" The game is a little old but that doesnt take away from its charm. It being older means the the graphics are not all HD/3D/VR-esque but are not too bad in hindsight. The story and quests drive you to want to go to the next part of the game and leveling is not that bad. The quests make it interesting to the point that it doesn't feel like a constant grind. Not to say that there isn't a grinding element to it.....it is a MMO after all.I'd give it a 9/10, just because I'm a fan of the books and they actually took the time to get it right.

												The game is great, if your style is grinding and free to play, then this game is for you, if your a huge fan of tolkien's work and his books, then this is for you for much of the  game's lore are very spot on. The community is very friendly, VERY VERY FRIENDLY,no exagerations. And if you want some Role Plays then this game has, much RPing are on Laurelin but some servers has it's rp.                         And a little tips for grinding Lotro Points (LP), use a minstrel dwarven so you will start at the very top of ered luin's map, why minstrel? It's because Minstrels are kinda OP (overpowered) at the starting levels (ered luin, the shire and bree-land), do all the slayer deeds and exploration deeds, if you do the quest then much better for it will complete a deed which will give you more than the slayer and exploration deeds, plus the reputation deeds you must do for it will give you 50 LP if you manage to complete all 4 of it, then after you've done all deeds at Ered Luin, do the same for The Shire ( I reccomend to do only the exploration and slayer deeds at the shire for the Quest deeds are kinda annoying :D, for reputation deeds,you need to be level 20 to use the Reputation Items, you can farm them at the old barrows or trade it in the skirmish camps) and Bree-land, eventually you can gather 800+ LP (Lotro Points) after you are done with the deeds.            It can be done for like 5-6 hours for all the starter region's deeds to be done, my record is kinda 4 and a half hours ( i use slayer deed acceleration and that thing that will give you boost on horse speed). This game has it's up's and downs like the dwindling numbers of players ( like the Dunedains XD, but there are players who came back after some months of not playing), much of the stuff in the game are fellowship (ex. Angmarm but you can solo almost everything that is important like Epic Quests).              My hours on record is 761.3 hrs but let me tell you that i have been playing it since 2012 and i have been using the stand alone client for almost 3 years, and the 2 years on steam. You are not alone in this game despite the few numbers of players, if you need help then you can ask for it in the WC (World Chat) and if you need for fellowship quest then look in the LFF chat box. God bless and Goodluck!

number of helpful: 18 of 22 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
er 6, 2013
												Free to play done right (and no it's not pay to win either :D ). Don't listen to folks who have one or two hours logged, you really can get a lot out of this game if you can put in some time and a little money. After all we all put time into games and some are bloody expensive!LoTRO is the least frustrating free to play experience I've had as Turbine gives you a taste of everything. They don't lock out 99% of the game. Completing 'deeds' (challenges like kill X amount of goblins) will earn you Turbine points for micro transactions in the LoTRO store. With enough time and patience its possible to buy several store items from in game rewards. If you spend even the minimum on Turbine points (£5) you get upgraded to premium account status. That gives you two more character slots per server and removes the gold cap.However if you're aiming not to spend anything at all you can't have a job or life and do that. That is some serious grinding. You'll also HAVE to spend time grinding the Turbine points if you don't even want to spend a fiver to remove the gold cap, as two gold is not nearly enough in game currency later on. Good thing is that before you remove the cap all money you earn gets saved in an overflow wallet ready for when you do gain access to it.WHAT FREE TO PLAYER'S GETThe epic quests that make up the main story line are mostly free (to continue it you need to buy the expansions).Player housing is free. Some items used to decorate can be bought in the store but most you get for free.Some trait slots are free. These are different to trait trees (the skill trees you spec into to get your abilities). You gain most of these by deeds and they can be slotted to give either passive buffs or more skills.Steeds. Getting your horse/pony/goat (can only ride goats in Moria) is a free option but the riding skill itself is not free. Don't throw your arms up in protest yet. With small effort you can get the 95 Turbine points you need to purchase this skill. Most deeds that award Turbine points (and most of them do) are worth between 5-10 points. Some deeds are worth more. It's easy to get (VIP's get a free quest that grants the skill). Some steeds are available in the store. With the Rohan expansion you can ride a war steed for mounted combat and customize it's appearance but that can get bloody expensive.The Shire, Bree, Ered Luin, Lone Lands and Celondim areas are free. Free, Premium and VIP players all have to buy the expansions, there are five in total. There are quest packs for other regions you can buy in game from about 595 Turbine points. You can travel to the areas you don't have the quest packs for, you just can't do quests there. It's important to note that free content (excluding skirmishes) drys up around level 35-38. Moria, the first expansion is best entered around level 50 so you'll be needing a quest pack to fill in the gap.Some skirmishes and repeatable instances are free.Joining a crafting guild is free but you need to pay for full access to it. You don't need be in a guild but it gives you access to far more recipes than you'd have otherwise. Having full access is a distinct advantage as there is far more choice.All but the Warden (one of the tanks) and Rune-Keeper (DPS and healing, not the only DPS or healing class in game) classes are free. The Rune-Keeper is well worth it, lots of ranged DPS magic fun. The Warden is more of a secondary tank with combos (called gambits) and other tricks thrown in.The fishing hobby (the only hobby) is free. You can catch fish to display in your home or to cook if you or any of your alts have the right crafting profession.The in game mailing system is free and is very useful to post items to your alts, not just other players.Creating a guild (known as a kinship here) is free (well it would be stupid otherwise lets face it).Free daily silver hobbit present.WHAT VIP's GETIf you go the subscription route you become a VIP. VIP's pay the following:$15 a month$29.97 for 3 months$59.94 for 6 months$99.99 for 12 monthsFor your chosen cost/sub length you get:Mailbox field access Access all character trait slots500 Turbine points per monthAccess all quest packs and skirmishes that are not a part of expansionsUnlimited chat20 Slots of shared wardrobe space (this enables you to cosmetically equip gear on any character)Additional inventory slotsCustom character portrait frameDaily +100% XP (for 30% of a level)Free weekly gold hobbit presentAccess all monster classes (Monster play is mostly PvP)Access all crafting guildsNo currency capMaximum auction house listingsThe most major benefits are the quest packs, skirmishes, 500 free Turbine points, crafting guilds and monster classes. That gives you a ton of extra content.PLAYING THE GAMEChoose race of men, hobbit, dwarf or elves, then pick your class. The usual DPS, tank and healer classes are present, along with the squishy pet class (Lore Master, that does more than just use pets). Next is the choice of where your character comes from. Choosing this region doesn't determine more than a preset skin tone and hair colour (which you can change). Choose your hair style, facial features etc, pick a suitable name and away you go. The level cap for characters is 100.The tutorial is easy and makes it clear how to use your abilities. A nice touch is the tutorial skip option available at character creation if you've already done it before.The usual MMO type features are here. Choose a crafting profession to make useful items along the way, level up and upgrade your weapons and armour, collect type quests, kill type quests, quests in instances as well as those in the open world. Most are set in the open world. There are also repeatable daily quests in certain areas. The interface makes it easy to see who is in your area if you want to start a fellowship (team). There are different instance quests called skirmishes. These can be repeated and are a bit more entertaining than the usual quests as they have a few different objectives and ambushes. You gain 'marks' for successful objectives as well as completing the skirmish itself. These can be completed solo or in a fellowship. Turn the marks in for rewards.When you start to level up you'll be getting trait points. Each class has three trait trees that will determine specifically how your chosen class plays and what skills you gain. Some skills however are not determined by which trees or how far into them you spec as they are standard skills. The Guardian (one of two tank classes) for example has a tanking, DPS and two handed tanking tree choices. You can choose to specialize in one tree or spread yourself a bit thinner into others as well.Being an MMO the graphics are not top notch but they are beautiful. Water effects are nice.USEFUL INFO ON CRASHESMany players have suffered from constant crashes. Check out post #11 in this thread;https://www.lotro.com/forums/showthread.php?521607-Lotro-keeps-crashingThat may solve your issues. Also if you have Pando Media Booster installed get rid of it! Not only is it pointless it can slow LoTRO to the point it crashes. Both these solutions worked for me and my wife.Yet again this is one of the vast amount of games these days that has annoying bugs. Hopefully you won't suffer them or at least be able to sort them with the above solutions. Also some of the store items are far too pricey (extra bags and anything steed related in particular).There's a lot of nice places to explore and plenty to do once you have a stable game. There are many more features I've not covered such as raids, PvP and monster play, not to mention the legendary weapon system and your free hobbit present you get each day. Have a bit of patience and you'll love Middle Earth. :)

ber 26, 2016
												Lord of the Rings Online is a must play for anyone that loves the world of Middle Earth, but the game itself is dated and suffers from a lack of cohesive game direction and meaningful new content. Character classes are interesting and engaging, and feel decently varied, but combat overall feels sluggish. The game used to have a great dungeon/raid system, but this has largely been replaced by the lackluster Big Battle system. Questing is largely comprised of standard kill and fetch quests, but the environments are varied and the storyline is a centerpoint. There isn't a meaningful catch up system though (unless you want to pay quite a bit of $$), so expect to spend quite a bit of time leveling if you're new to the game.The graphics are beautiful but dated. Character creation is a bit lackluster, but the world itself is where the game really shines.The music is excellent, and really captures the feeling of Middle Earth. At times it's a bit repetetive, but this is balanced by the ability to create your own music in game.

content:
7, 2016
												The Lord of the Rings Online is by far the Best MMORPG I've kind of played.  I was a late to the game, but I subbed for a few months with some friends (and even more since f2p).  The fellowship quests and group content is as solid as it gets for old school MMORPGs.  A time came when new and shiny things came and Lotro was left behind for me and my pals, But I still go back every now and then.  I love the rich lore/story, the fantastic graphics (even today they look good), and the truley epic settings.LOTRO at first glance when playing is odd.  I totally understand when someone says they just didn't like it.  Yet at it's core, this game is as good if not better than any MMORPG made during it's time.  It just does things a little differently.  For instance it tries really hard to stick to the books (the I.P it draws from-not the movies) so there are no mages or wizard classes bc the only Wizards are the famous ones - (Gandorf, Radhadgas, Sarapmon). There are however classes who play like mages using knowledge of powders (Lore Master), ancient runes (Rune Keeper), and...music (Minstrel).  There are no "hit points" or health.  The green bar is morale, and when it reaches zero you die..so yeah its health, but not really, and some abilities are just silly like the crowd control Burglar ability "riddle" (in the heat of combat you tell a riddle and the enemy thinks about it for like 20 secs).  Thats what Lotro does.  It holds true to the lore of the book and the world it created.  Each class is very fun and there are quite a few 'one of a kind' classes in Lotro. So often mmos copy paste classes.  At the start of the game, the music is not great, your gear looks like barf, and you're screaming at enemies to do damage. It's different and these can push ppl away, but the music is optional, lotro has an amazing (before it's time) outfit/wardrobe system that is fully customizable with dyes and overlays, and screaming at enemies lowers their morale so get over it. The main reason I don't play it very much is the lack of friends who will play it.  Like many MMORPGs back then, playing with friends is a tricky and often demanding experience.  Need to be on the same server, and need to be near the same levels. Servers have merged, players are a bit low, but It's still good and the Free to play model isn't horrible.  You can do anything by grinding Deeds.  The f2p model locks out questing zones and trait slots, and sometimes the paygates get annoying, but if you don't care to grind deeds it's really not that big of a deal.  Especially if you make alts bc their deeds count towards the in game currency too.  If you are a fan of Lord of the Rings in any form, nothing beats exploring and visiting all of the awesome iconic places you've only read about or seen in movies.  Give it a try! I know I will as long as it's still alive.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 19
												In recent reviews, people have complaints about long installation times, trouble with registering, and not being able to play the game. For me, this was not the case. I don't have a powerful rig (and also not the best wifi), and I downloaded this game in under an hour. With quick account registration and patches installed, I was soon on my way to explore Middle Earth.As for the game itself, for being almost 10 years old, it's incredible. As a fan of Tolkien, it's astonishing to run into iconic landscapes and characters. The game is beautiful for being 10 years old, and you don't need a high performancing PC to run it. There's a main quest line that follows the books and plenty of interesting side quests. Combat is fun and engaging for a tab target MMORPG. The music, oh the music. If you're a fan of the Lord of the Rings film scores, then you'll love the music in game. There's nothing more enjoyable than the ear-gasm of riding into Rohan and hearing the sweet sound of violins accompaning your journey.On the contrary, the game can become a bit grindy. Lower level quests can become quite repeditive with the feeling of "kill 10 spiders and collect 5 bear hides.," can be a bit overwhelming. I know. I've almost stopped playing again because of it. But, if you pick an advanced and interesting class, it can be less mind numbing. At the time of writting this review, I have a level 20 Warden and quests are becoming more engaging. Skirmishes, epic battles, and instances are a great break from these grindy experiences, and epic battles are available at low levels.As for the F2P model, it's one of the best ones available. It's incredibly fair and there really isn't any P2W instances. Some higher level quests and expansions require LOTRO points, but these points can be acquired in game (if you're up for some serious grinding). Most of the equipment found in the LOTRO store are cosmetics, mounts, and chracter boosts. I started out as a F2P player, but fell in love with the game, and became a VIP member, spending some money on additional LOTRO Points.So download the game. If you don't like it, then all you have done is wasted a bit of your time. It's free to play people. With another expansion coming out this year and another playable race, download it now and enjoy an authentic Middle Earth experience.

The main story ties in well with the story from the books and you play as a character helping out from behind the scenes. I haven't played too much so far, but i'm invested in the game and expect to be playing it for a very long time! Don't let the fact that the game was released in 2007 put you down because this game is utterly amazing! See ya, off to play some more Lord of the Rings Online!Overall score: 9.3/10

content:
y 9, 2014
												Unsurprisingly, given the number of hours played, I find this f2p MMO really enjoyable. The recent (2013) introduction of trait trees has somewhat dumbed down the gameplay and has particularly hurt support classes, making them less useful in raid situations. The Helms Deep battles however have added some level of strategic play which may compensate some players for the loss of complexity elsewhere. Of course new players will not experience the loss felt by long term players to the complexity of play and can just enjoy the excellent epic storyline and the great graphics (these improve as you level and reach regions that have been created more recently), but all the areas look pretty as long as you have a half way decent graphics card.Skirmish and instance (dungeon) play does not become available until you reach lvl 20. Thereafter as you level up more areas of play become available.  It is worth buying the packs as you get more areas to explore and some decent perks. Although you can earn these in game if you are willing to grind Turbine points. 92:100

content:
er 28, 2016
												Let me start out by saying I actually love this game...The problem is, despite being "F2P" it really isn't...unless I suppose you have 3,000 hours to grind LOTRO points, but even then, there's no way you could afford to purchase everything you need to play the game unrestricted. I purchased this game almost 9 years ago, before it went "F2P." Despite owning the actual game, they still said I had to purchase the level 20+ zone, which I already bought when I purchased the game, or subscribe before I could play it. Like I said, I love this game, so I subbed. Once I got to level 65, I found out that just having a sub wasn't enough to access the later content. I then needed to spend roughly $20 or so to access content for the next 10 levels, then another $20 for the next 10 levels and yet another probably $40 in LOTRO points to afford the end game content. This, again, wouldn't be a huge deal except the game is pretty lifeless at the non-endgame levels, making it ridiculous to have to spend nearly $100 plus what I already subbed to get to the end game where the small playerbase "hangs out." Having a sub should be enough to at least get you to the content before the latest end-game stuff.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
2016
												First of all - I've spent countless hours in this game before I finally downloaded it through steam when I had to re-install it due to hardware problems. The Lord of the Rings Online boasts a great open world based on J.R.R. Tolkien's famous works. Here you get to explore Middle-earth at your own pace, together with friends or all alone. Since LOTRO was first launched in 2007, it has grown from being a fairly small MMO to be among the biggest and broadest worlds out there. You can explore famous sites as seen in the movies and read about in the books, such as the Shire, Bree-town, Weathertop, Rivendell, Isengard, Helms Deep and as of one of the more recent updates, Minas Tirith! And not only do you get to see these landmarks, but you can also explore everything inbetween. Okay, you can't go everywhere straight off. In fact there is alot you'll have to go through to get to Gondor and Minas Tirith, but the story and places you visit on your way is just so masterfully created. You create your own character and you get to be the hero of Middle-earth in your own adventure paralell to the travels of Frodo and the fellowship. You'll see sides of Middle-earth that you never really noticed in either the books or films before. And the best thing about LOTRO is that it is completely free to play! Okay, you can buy Turbine Points and VIP membership to help you on your adventures. But it is also completely possible to farm Turbine Points in-game and get to the level cap, which is currently at level 105, without spending a single real-life dollar. I recommend this game to anyone who has a slight interest in Tolkien's work, be it the books or the movies based on them. I also recommend it to anyone who likes a good MMORPG and wants to try something a little different. Because LOTRO is different from other MMO's. Not only does it have by far the most established lore of any MMO, but it also has one of the very best player communities. Sure, there are a few jerks in Middle-earth too, just as there are in any other place, but overall the LOTRO community is among the friendliest and most helpful communities out there. The only con I can state about this game right now is that since it's come so far in development it is a little hard for new players and those of us, me included, who's taken a longer break from the game, to catch up with the newest content. But luckily, the friendly community has got you covered! If you ask for help, I bet you're gonna get it!

												If LOTRO had come out first, I likely never would have played WoW. (That is saying something, as I have played WoW since release and still have an active account) I've been a fan of Tolkien's world and writing since I was a little girl and have worn out multiple copies of The Hobbit.LOTRO can be complex to learn (I'm a minstrel and I play infrequently.) and the store can be daunting. However, I bought the game when it came out so I had a few nice little perks like extra slots and bags etc. If you "rush to the endgame" content you will be disappointed. I'm not particularly fond of instances etc, but I love wandering around on my Minstrel and seeing the world. I enjoyed meeting Tom Bombadil (and helping him with a few things) and participating in a few festivals with the Hobbits.If you are looking for an MMO where you get obscenely powerful and faceroll all the content hit up something different. LOTRO is a bit dated, but, I had great fun with all the quests (enough so that I will probably make another alt) and I come back to it every year for a month or so, get a few more levels on my Minstrel (I'll never get max level, of that I am sure!) and enjoy a change of pace from everything else I play.

content:
30, 2016
												I've been playing for 3 years now, a little over 5000 hours.  The game is a beautiful interpretation of Tolkien's lore, and a fantastic rendition of Middle Earth.  If you enjoy the journey, rather than rushing to cap, it's perfect.  Many of the quests are interesting, some funny, some touching, a few a bit over the top with the running back and forth.  Exploring is always fun, you never know what's around the corner.  The devs have hidden little "Easter Eggs" throughout the landscape- a little cabin in the woods housing 3 bears, the occaisional bear-skin rug with a rabit sitting on it, and many others.  Hidden deeds suprise you with a new title when you accomplish an objective you didn't even know you were going for.  These are just the extras, as the whole point of your journey is to help in the background as the Fellowship persues thier goal.  I love it, and the community.  The vast majority of players are helpful and friendly, ready to advise, assist, and inform.  Try it, you have nothing to lose, and a whole world of enjoyment to gain.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
r 27, 2016
												As most I started playing the game when it went free to play. I was very interested in playing an mmo in the universe created by Tolkien. At first the game may not seem attractive due to the outdated graphics, the clunky combat and the somewhat repetitive questing. However, if you invest a good amount of time to understand it the game starts showing its jewels. As you progress through the areas you will feel your character getting stronger, becoming a seasoned warrior whose path is tied with that of the Fellowship. The main story line not only lets you experience the Lord of the Rings trilogy to its depth but also gives you an insight on secondary plotlines that were in the background of both the books and the movies.A major advantage of the game is that it literally lets you get every part of the premium content by grinding. You can get every expansion, dungeon, skirmish e.t.c. by doing the abundant deeds spread out through all the areas. I have never seen something similar in other similar MMOs. Another great aspect of the game which adds to its immersion is the community. Everyone is very helpful to each other, bad game practices are non-existant making you feel like a member of a large fellowship.Overall, I believe people who like me are fans of the universe Tolkien created would adore this game as its huge content lets you experience the history of the books as if you were there.

content:
ry 16, 2016
												I used to play this game until they released a patch which which broke the musical instruments so I left the game with sadness in my heart.You may wonder why I would have instruments as a reason to leave the game, so allow me to ellaborate;Once long, long ago I began my journey in LotRO as soon as it was released on Steam. I had thoroughly enjoyed the books and loved the movies to an equal measure so I decided to see what kind of game the MMO would be like.The experience was honestly the best I had ever had out of an MMO up until that point and I loved it down to the core of my heart. I loved exploring around the vast maps on my mount, dismounting to farm and complete quests and then return to uncover more story and venture deeper into more and more locations.The I found instruments but didn't know about how to use them correctly so I left them to one side.Eventually during my adventures I caught up to a group of people in the same area who were courteous to me and even allowed me to join them in their party so that we could all complete the quests faster and adventure together.Not long later they invited me to their Skype group and we would talk and play LotRO for hours on end. Slaying everything from the lowly mobs to major bosses and we would do so joyously.Then one person in the group stated they had been looking online at guides and forums and had stumbled across ABC files. These were essentially MIDI files that were programmed to work with instruments in LotRO. We messed around with them initially until someone in the group had the brilliant idea of synchronising our music by counting down in Skype and beginning to play the same song simultanbeously.We did so and the result was fantastic; we were essentially a small orchestra of terribly mismatched instruments but the sound was fantastic to us nontheless. Not only this but when we began to do this in centers of population like towns and hubs other players began to gather around in small crowds and use dance emotes as we played the Star Wars theme tune, MJ's Smooth Criminal, the Pirates of the Carribean theme tune and so on.Even though this had nothing to do with the game itself it was as if we had created a tiny meta-game within LotRO which we as a group resided and we even stopped questing as a whole. We simply went from town to town as a traveling band and it was the best time I have probably ever had in an MMO. It was also an extremely unique experience. Never in my life had I ever played an online game in order to avoid playing the online game in favour of doing some stupid pointless thing and it was still so enjoyable.Then the updates happened. Not only did servers begin to die out and disappear but they eventually released a patch which broke the instruments. HOW they broke the instruments, items which have literally no impact on the rest of the game or needed modifying or changing in any way shape or form is still beyind me, but they did and this crushed my heart and the hearts of my fellow group. We had spent what mjust have been three or four moths running aroudn playing music and being generally stupid while occasionally helping lower level people who required assistance withing quests.We unanimously decided to all leave the game. The thing which had become the core gameplay to us long after the grindy and repetitive combat had become stale was lost.We waited for a few weeks. We posted many complaints. There were quite a lot of forum posts. But this was to no avail. After each passing week the desire to return to LotRO had subsided and I have never return since.This in it's entirety is the tale of my LotRO experience. Although it may not be the most useful or the most interesting this is how I viewed the game during my playtime and the reason why I abandoned it.P.S. If under any circumstance they have fixed the instruments please reply to this so that people will know if they have not played the game but my desire to play is no longer here so I will not be returning regardless, thank you.

content:
er 16, 2014
												I have been playing Lords of the Rings Online (LOTRO) since it went to free to play in 2010.  I just loaded LOTRO from Steam recently.   LOTRO has been my favorite MMORPG, since City of Heroes was closed.  I have bought all the quest packs, expansions and many unlocks for my one account. I only play on the Gladden server.LOTRO is called a "Free to Play" MMORPG in the description, but if you want to reach level cap in LOTRO, you will have to pay some real money.  Free to Play accounts are limited on purpose, of course. Free to Play only have the landscape enemies, all the epic story quests, few instances, some instant action quests, 3 starter areas and 1 area lvl 20 to 30, and can make 2 characters which have to buy trait powers, bags, swift travel, gold cap unlock, etc. The Devs are quite generous with awarding store points for just playing LOTRO and the game is more Free To Play friendly than others.  You can grind for store points by completing deeds on each character on your account, but you would have to work very hard to earn enough just to buy 1 quest pack.  You can also Google for guides to show you how to earn enough store points to Play for Free, check the Steam guides also.I suggest you try it out from Steam as Free to Play only, up to level 32. Then if you really want to pay, go to the in-game store to set up credit card payments. The best way to play LOTRO, imho, is to pay for the all the Expansions and Quest packs, then take VIP for 1 month, then create all your characters, then play for free as Premium account.   Expansions have to be bought separately, even for VIP players, but can be bought with store points in-game.  Paying for VIP for 1 month will unlock all the stuff for each character you open that you would have to buy separately.  With store points, you are able to unlock alot of things that VIP players get for free, and are in premium and free accounts to annoy them. Get the account Wallet also. The LOTRO store has a lot of sales on points bundles and items in store.  Don't expect payments from the Steam wallet to work, but it has worked at one time.If you have problems running this game while loaded from Steam, then download it straight from the LOTRO dot com website.  If you are a Mac user, and have problems playing this game then switch to a Windows OS computer.There is no pvp servers, just special pvp maps for level 105 subscribers to fight player controlled monsters.  You get a Orc Warrior (Reaver) for free with any character on that server reaching level 10.  The rest of the Creep classes are buyable using store points.  You can pvp on the same side by sparring but there is no rewards for that.LOTRO is a massively multiplayer online role-playing game set in a fantasy universe based upon J. R. R. Tolkien's Middle-Earth novels. It takes place during the time period of The Lord of the Rings movies. The graphics and controls are good still.  The level cap currently is 105 and there is plans for more expansions. The game like all other MMORPGs that has it's faults but it is better than the other games out there currently still, imho.  There are still plenty of hardcore and new players on the remaining open servers, after there has been a server consolidation in 2016. Standing Stone games is the original development team and have shifted producer to Daybreak game in 2017.  Has a great Crafting system. There are plenty of raids, dungeons and instant action content. Try this game out if you like fantasy MMORPGs.for more info:

content:
2016
												So after 500 hours I guess its time to write a review.No matter which game I play, I always seem to come back to Lotro. It has its flaws, but yet there is just something special about it. The community in general are always helpful and willing to help out new players, and after the server migrations the world feels much more populated. Even if you are not a fan of J.R.R Tolkien's work, I would still recommend you try this game for at least the first 30 levels, as you would not have to buy a single thing until then.Pros:- Great Community- The only game that allows you to explore most of Middle-Earth- Very active RP groups if you are interested in that- Hundreds of hours of content- Possible to play this game completely free (You can earn Turbine points by doing deeds in-game)- PvP is fun, as you can play either as the Free Peoples, or as Sauron's ArmyCons:- The game is old, so even though it still looks very good, the outdated graphics might put some people off- There is a lot that you would need to purchase or grind for, if you do not pay a monthly sub.- Server issues can cause lag quite a lot, especially in PvP, though in general it is fine- Balance issues with some classes, though the game is still being actively developed and balancedSo overall, I would score Lotro a 8/10, and would recommend anyone looking for a decent MMO or just a fun game to try it out.Edit: 1300 hours and review still stands, loving it so far!
