content:
1, 2016
												As a 7 year veteran of this game that has purchased every expansion/class/zone I cannot in good faith recommend this game anymore, Turbine have no idea what they are doing at this point and are obviously suffering from lack of staff and have been since Riders of Rohan launched.Turbine apparently decided a game wide nerf was in order because content was too easy, huge sweeping changes like this couldn't possibly affect anything right? NPC's in escort missions were hit by this nerf and in turn had their HP lowered to an absolutely rediculous amount causing some key story missions to be almost impossible until completely outleveling them (96 to do a level 87 required mission) requiring you to completely bypass doing the games main story (the key reason I enjoy it and play it) and do sidequests until you are able to go back and play catch up. If you managed to complete this story before the game wide nerf you were fine. This is insanely unacceptable to require the player to be almost a full 10+ levels higher to complete in order to finish the quest.Also of note is the absolutely abysmal or almost complete lack of optimization in the recent expansions. To put this in perspective I have trouble maintaining 15 FPS on ultra in areas with a fairly decent rig (R9 390X, i7 4790k, 32g DDR3). This game was released in 2007. I have no trouble maintaining 100+ FPS in Final Fantasy XIV on max settings. The game functions atrociously on anything above a dual core cpu and it shows. Mounted combat has been laggy and suffers from rubber banding regardless of connection since it was implemented in 2012 with no improvements, something that was touted as a main mechanic and the entire expansion was centered around. The game also suffers from extreme hitching regardless of settings/zone in every expansion past Riders of Rohan due to the way the engine is structured and reads files from an HDD, this is not fixed using an SSD or flash drive as the devs suggest in the forums.This is completely depressing as this is easily in my top 3 MMO's I've played. I love the community and the setting for this game; I have genuinely never met nicer people in an MMO than I have in this. I enjoyed being able to create my own character and explore an absolutely gorgeous world and I really enjoyed seeing an expanded form of the LOTR universe and being a part of new stories told in it.Maybe by some amazing stroke of luck the game can magically obtain a development team that is substantial enough and experienced enough to fix the problems with the game and restore it to the game I once enjoyed spending my time in, but until then the game is on life support and future updates will likely not fix the issues the game currently has.

content:
ry 9
												Put it simple: the best MMORPG out there.It's big. What do you think is big? WoW? Check this. If you pay attention, you'll notice that any other MMORPG uses either corridor-like locations, with view always blocked by mountains, trees, buildings etc., or dramatically low draw distance, or both. Well, LotRO draws enormously vast locations with honest draw distance - not GTA V, but nothing like you've seen in MMORPG before. (The Crew was later). When you're in the fields of Rohan, you feel exactly why it is the land of horseriders.It's authentic. I play this game for 7 years and still I stop and gaze in awe at dwarf lords sculptures in Moria. Still I take screenshots of The Shire. Still I find dozens of new landscape details. This world is handcrafted by the indigenous inhabitants of Middle-Earth - piece by piece, tree by tree, bush by bush.It's homely. LotRO officially has the best or one of the best communities in online games.You know, I can go down to the basic mechanics, the classes (see in comments), the raids, the PvP, the unique mechanics like Legendary Weapons and Mounted Combat, but you know what? It's boring. Every game has mechanics, classes, balance and lots of people whine there's no balance. But this game is special. It has... it IS The Middle-Earth. If this means nothing to you, just pass by. You will like it, or dislike it, nothing I can change. But if you love Middle-Earth as I do, or if you are ready to fall in love with it, then whe shall meet at the White City. One day.Over 4000 hours /played on Russian servers before they were shut down.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
3, 2014
												Ever wondered to explore Middle-Earth and see the town of Bree, the greens of the Shire and the beauty of Rivendell through your very own eyes? Or perhaps you aspire to be a warrior of the Free Peoples by wielding a shield with as much expertise as shield-master Boromir or string an arrow to the bow as elegantly as the archer Legolas and leave a pile of Orcs in your wake?The Lord of the Rings Online offer all those opportunities and more. Excellent graphics means that you really feel the whole Middle Earth experience when you walk through the town of Bree and into the Prancing Pony for a glass beer or mug of ale. And yes, LOTRO will let you do that!Having spent the past few years of my life playing this game in my free time, I will admit that initially downloaded the game not knowing what to expect of LOTRO's idea of Middle Earth but now many years later, I am proud to say that I've got the chance to do deeds that would make Aragorn consider leaving Arwen for. Or make Boromir betray Gondor - if that makes more sense to you.From simple solo exploring of the fields of the Shire to raiding up with up to 23 other people (24 in total) to fight the likes of vile creatures such as Balrogs and Dragons, LOTRO has it. A good combat skill and trait system allows for dynamic fights and variety of gameplay amongst the various classes. Feel like wielding a shield and turning into a unstoppable version of a defensive god or grasping a greatblade and breaking the Middle-Earth record of "number of Uruks killed"? Then make it happen by playing LOTRO.Taking all of the above into account and adding on things like a wide choice of mounts for players, a flexible and in-depth crafting system, unique legendary items, player housing filled with the Balrog's Sword (a loot dropped from killing him) makes The Lord of the Rings Online THE MMO to play.Take your first baby steps in Middle-Earth by giving this game a try - who knows, you might even get into the history books found in the Library of Rivendell.Forward onto victory! Forward...FOR GONDOR!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2016
												Undying for its iconic interactive portrayal of Tolkien's world, LOTRO has had its fair share of problems lately, but it still remains a fun and memorable game.Pros:+it features a lot of the places and events from the book+contains a very vast world, whose variety truly makes you feel like you're on an adventure+the dialogues do manage to awake some of the nostalgia which made the book so powerful+class advancement, though not special from other MMOs, is still quite decent+the story part of the quests is more developed than in many other MMOsCons:-the graphics is pretty much outdated-overall, Turbine's marketing techniques tend to be a bit aggressive and dishonest. Besides, the F2P system is quite tricky. Don't go into the game imagining you can play it up until the final level without paying anything, because that's very nearly impossible. -shallow dialogues, inaccurate portrayals of iconic places, uninteresting new landscapes-repetitive quests and often grinding, though not more than in other MMOs-the last updates have been quite disappointing in terms of the originality of the contentNeutral:-the PvP system is promising and quite enjoyable already, but it is also poorly uninvested inDespite its many issues, I would still recommend LOTRO for its landscapes, story and lore, at least for a try. If you do not like it, you may give up before hitting the level where you actually need to start paying money to advance properly. But just don't go into it with the impression that you'll reach max level entirely for free (like in GW2), because, even though technically it's possible, it's extremely difficult and will ruin the fun of it even if attempted.

content:
28, 2016
												The atmosphere is great, especially in Moria and some other areas. The community is good, and combat is enjoyable.That said, quests are awful in every way, there is no dialogue whatsoever, a lot of places are badly-designed, cosmetically and practically (Minas Tirith, I'm looking at you), and class balance is not great (poor hunters). Don't bother playing without a subscription or good hardware, either - most of the game requires cash to access (including class-critical abilities), and later areas are laggy.The character building/equipment system is a joke, especially since essences.- There's a whole bunch of base and derived stats (maybe 25-35, depending on how you count), but only a third is actually relevant. The remaining stats come free when gearing for the important third.- There are sixteen equipment slots (plus legendary items, which are class features, not items), but they all do exactly the same: they exist only to dump armour with lots of essence slots into. Yes, there are set bonuses, but you could easily reduce the whole equipment system to, say, six numbers (# of four kinds of essences, # of two kinds of equipment set).- Overall, there is a semblance of complexity, but successive updates only seem to replace the need to think about your equipment with more grind-based power creep.- To be clear, combat is fine. It's just that char-op is boring.I don't recommend it, because I don't like it (anymore). However, if you're not interested in deep character building systems, you like being monologued at by NPCs (in LoTR-style speech), and you don't mind a bit of grind, it's otherwise a good game.

content:
2, 2016
												Horrible F2P Model, And An Incredibly Boring Solo ExperienceSo many pointless restrictions to F2P playersWhatever you wanna do, you are always reminded of the store, and there will be always something blocking you unless you get VIP (Premium) or buy Turbine Points (or endlessly grind for them)Your wallet is capped to 2 gold, which is no-where near enough for people who are level 20+Your ability to use the Auction feature (Global Trade/Multiplayer Market) and sell your items is locked, you need to buy "slots". Each "slots" purchase gives you 3 slots to sell your items. Pathetic and not nearly enoughYou need to buy a "Mount Skill" in order to use the mounts in-game, which are desperatly needed since your character in-game is stupidly super slowAny basic features you need to use that are provided for free and easy to use in any other F2P MMORPG, you need to grind and spend hours on end just to use in this gameThere is such a heavy focus on the LotRO Store and the game practically forces you to buy into their stupid VIP Premium crap, and punishes you if you don'tLoTRO is just a P2W exploited gameAll the pointless restrictions can be unlocked, via the LotRO Shop, by doing "Deeds"But Deeds are just a boring, endless grind of killing the same monsters that take hours on end just to turn up with afew Turbine Points (LoTRO Shop Currency). You get 15 Turbine Points for about an hours worth of grinding the same, slowly respawning Monster, and some of the lower costing features is around 95 Turbine pointsThe game is incredibly boring, and just a long boring choreIt's just jam-packed with courier missions that make you back and foward from one town to another, to transport an item, give a letter to someone, or tell someone something. Things slowly pick up by level 20, but not nearly enough to make the game fun or intrestingTL;DR - The game is one long, boring, P2W choreI highly advice you to stay away from this game, it's really not worth your time unless you're willing to drop so much money into this game

er 27, 2015
												The steam review system is keeping me from posting my original, longer review, so here, in a nutshell:- Used to be such a great game, with an awesome community, much respect for the lore and the books etc. - Ever since the F2P conversion, there is more and more focus on the store.- Just came back after a long break (have played since launch, but took long breaks), and I can't try any of the new content as I have to unlock the zones and their quests. So either have to sub, buy TP or do insane grinds. - Even if I was remotely interested in either of that, the fact that there are still SO many bugs keeps me from doing so. Within 10 minutes, I saw such incredibly horrible rubberbanding on my warsteed (which was something people complained about when this system came OUT in 2012), that I don't wanna see more.- Game feels empty now, hardly saw any players, my formerly big and active guild is deserted now- Whatever you wanna do, you are always reminded of the store, and there will be always something blocking you unless you sub or buy TP (or grind)I am saddened by what the game has become. It was so immersive, had such a great community (especially on Laurelin-RP), but now feels empty and abandoned, and for a returning player, there is hardly any motivation to stick around and come back because everything is locked unless you pay. So this "F2P" feels more like an extended trial. I have no issues with F2P, many games do it so much better though.This is just a shadow of its former glory, and the few minutes I just spent after my last hiatus gave me no reason at all to ever come back.

content:
ry 12, 2016
												Considerations of this game from most important to least:-It's free to play (truly) -it remains about as faithful to true Lord of the Rings lore as any game has ever done so far-bonuses that are available to players who pay premium can be acquired by free-to-play players by doing a nominal amount of grinding (and if you want to get the expansions for free, you can grind a hell of a lot and still manage to get those as well) -game is entirely playable as a single player if you so desire (offering power ups at key story points if you don't have a group)-a very friendly community of players that is extremely helpfulHonestly, the only downside that I see to this game is that once you reach roughly level 30 (which does not take a ton of time - I reached level 20 after a few days of playing) things start to take a lot more time.  This is because a lot of the features in the game, such as fast-travel, mile-stone bindpoints (teleportation points), and upgraded mounts aren't available immediately to free-to-play players.  That is not to say that mounts are entirely unavailable to free-to-play players however, a mount is available to any character at roughly level 20.  Obviously it is necessary for the company to provide services that must be paid for in order to keep the game running, and considering the fact that an entirely new player could go into the game and immediately start playing what would be roughly 70% of the game content without spending a penny; that is a pretty good deal.  Not to mention that, as i said previously, if you grind 'turbine points' in game enough, you can collect enough to pay for all of the expansions - granted it would take a long time, but it is certainly possible.All in all, i would rate this game 9/10.  The point loss is purely because there are still a few extremely minor inaccuracies in the game that are noticeable to Lord of the Rings fans who are extremely knowledgeable to the lore.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2014
												LOTRO is an excellent "visualization" of J. R. R. Tolkien's Trillogy - The Lord of the Rings. It is based solely on the books, and therefor differs from the Peter Jackson movie version -- which took significant liberties with the books. There is no "Dwarf Tossing" or "Shield surfing" in Helms Deep to just pick two glaring examples.The world of Middle Earth is huge, and contains many "easter eggs" from both the books and Tolkien's life. At present, November 2014, LOTRO has no "end-game" - it has only just begun the third book of the Trillogy, and will probably not reach the Black Gate until 2016. But while we hope Sam and Frodo reach Mount Doom on their own, there is much to do to clean-up Sauron's deviltry in the rest of the world.There is much to do in Middle Earth. 29 Servers provide a wealth of opportunity for players to create different characters for each of the four races - Dwarf, Elf, Man and Hobbit; and in each of the classes - Hunter, Champion, Guardian, Captain, Minstrel, Lore-master, and with the appropriate expansions, Rune-keeper, Warden and the just introduced Beorning. Players can create characters on each server!The Fan-run website: https://lotro-wiki.com/index.php/Main_Page provides a wealth of information about the game, from items and quests, to background lore.

content:
ber 18, 2016
												People complain a great deal about The Lord of the Rings Online in how it isn't immersive with its dialogue, or lack thereof, and other rather old MMO elements. So World of Warcraft and Star Wars Galaxies were not great games either that followed this game doctrine?LOTRO is an exceptional example of an MMO for fans of the books, movies, and newcomers alike. The player-base is smaller than others, but this leads to a community that is more friendly, and charitable. That is one of the best parts about this game also: the community. In LOTRO, you won't find many toxic people (At least, on my server, Crickhollow). I bought this game the day it came out, and have had the luxury to see how it evolved since then, and the toxocity has not increased much (but, this game is free, so expect some bad apples).The MMO is also very relaxed, meaning that if you are used to super-competitive MMOs, and want to retreat from it all, LOTRO is a great game to relieve that built-up tension. The crafting system is also elaborate, and fun to do as well, with crafters even giving some of their finished work for free to players in need.The attention to detail involving the world of Middle-Earth is very accurate to how J.R.R. Tolkien wrote it (not how Peter Jackson tried to erase it in the movies), with famous characters, places, and events all happening that fans read about. I can compare this to Star Wars Galaxies (RIP), where you are sort of "Along for the ride" with the major plot.Overall, LOTRO is one of the best MMOs out there right now, if you don't want to remove your scarf and thick-framed glasses and play WoW (tried WoW, got bored of it the same way the people who gave this MMO negative reviews did). So many elements encompass the greatness of this rather obscure, and in some ways forgotten, MMO. I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes MMOs, give it a shot, it is free after all!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
28, 2015
												Yes the game is old, but so are the books that the game's based on.The lore is there, and the areas are there, almost as good as the books. The main story (epic quests) has you following the fellowship (or running parallel), working in the background to fight the rising evil, aiding the good cause.You will quest around landmarks from the books like Weathertop, and you can find little touches like the petrified trolls in the Trollshaws.It may not have the best graphics (but certainly not the worst either). I grew up with a Commodore 64, so gameplay is more important than graphics for me, but things like the use of lighting to set the mood works really well for me, as does the weather.It is F2P, but that doesn't mean it doesn't cost a thing to have all content available.The good thing is that the store credits (Turbine Points) can be earned in-game, and that you can buy almost everything that is included in the VIP status with it. The only notable exception is 'fast travel' which you really will miss if you haven't got it, as the game is BIG.The bad thing is that earning TP quickly is a grind, although it can be sped up if you have some high level characters.Combat is old school skill clicking, which you either like or dislike.Crafting is extremely simple; you have the mats, you make the item. (with a % to critical success). I would have liked something more involving, like EverQuest II's crafting perhaps.Crafting does require interaction with other players, as you won't be able to get all materials you need yourself for the crafts you choose.If you are into PvP, then this game is not for you.There is some sort of PvP (PvMP), where some players have a character on the evil side, and some players play their regular 'good' side characters. There's one map for it, and the PvP crowd varies wildly per server.If you are into endgame raids, then this game is not for you. There is no (new) endgame content. There are scaling instances, which are essentially the same from L20 upwards, except with harder enemies.There is some new endgame content in the making though.Most of the population is helpful and mature, but, as this is an online game, there are some trolls and trouble makers on the chat channels. Although vocal, this is a very small group compared to the helpful people.Oh, one major bad thing: The download is HUGE, and the update process is extremely slow compared to other MMOs.Overall: If you like the Lord of the Rings lore (whether from the books or the movies) and like to explore Middle Earth yourself, then this is the only game to play.It's free up to around L30, after which you need to unlock quests for other areas.Whether you pay for it with money or with time is up to you, which is a fair deal IMO.And remember, the journey is more important than the goal.

31, 2015
												If you like MMOs and you like LOTR then this is literally the best thing ever. (If you just like MMOs and don't really know much about LOTR then it still might be the best thing ever.) It isn't pay to win IF you are committed because by completing challenges (called deeds) you can earn points (Turbine Points) that you can then use to purchase the expansions or quest packs. However, if you are impatient like me then you might end up spending 50 bucks, which isn't really a bad idea if you like the game because it's supporting the devs!The scenery and places you can go are amazing. The game is practically a 1:1 scale of Middle Earth (don't quote me because I know this isn't true...). The gameplay doesn't really get monotonous like most MMOs, because the quests are very fun to do (especially in a group). JUST DON'T DO QUESTS IN THE SHIRE BECAUSE ALL THEY ARE IS GETTING SENT BACK AND FORTH BETWEEN 2 HOBBITS THAT ARE LITERALLY 100 FEET AWAY FROM EACH OTHER. The community is probably one of the friendliest I have ever had to pleasure to play with. Most of the players are a really good sport and are very helpful if you ask questions. If you are into RPing then this is one of the best places to go because the RP system is pretty kickass and the RPers know what they're doing.My review may not be the best, but hopefully with this one and some of the others, we get a new member to the LOTRO family!(and remember that it IS free to play so you can always try it! If you don't like it just delete it!)

content:
, 2015
												I've been playing this game since it became free to play, and I feel like every update since has been making the game better and better for me. I'm a big fan of Middle Earth and getting to see bits of lore that you don't experience in film (like Tom Bombadil for instance) really helps bring this world to life. I love the emphasis on kindness and friendship, and following the epic storyline makes you feel like you are a part of this world and that you all matter.As far as gameplay goes, I feel it is fairly standard in terms of controls - easy to get the hang of once you learn the differences from other games. Some people may not agree with the locking out of certain features in-game for free players, but these are easily unlockable with enough effort and determination without having to spend a penny. I personally did end up subscribing for a few months to unlock a lot of content. Since then, I am always considered a premium account and I keept a lot of the features that were unlocked with subscribing.This is my favorite free to play MMORPG out there at this time.

content:
19
												     Out of all the games I have played in my entire life, The Lord of the Rings Online (LotRO) has been the most detailed and beautiful game I have ever come across. The story emulates Tolkein's original work, and as a LotR fan, I appreciate that. The graphics of this game are not top-notch, but compared to other MMOs and MOBAs I have played (Archeage, DDO, Smite, Rift, etc.), the graphics are much better. The music in this game is nothing short of phenomenal, as Chance Thomas's compositions are eloquent, detailed, and blend in with the scenery of the game. The game itself is immersive in nature. I have played for up to twelve hours at a time without even noticing (recovering LotRO addict). LotRO offers VIP subscription, but it is not needed. Regions and the LotRO quad pack can be bought with LotRO Points (either buy them or acquire them by completing deeds). For those who want to have a VIP subscription, it only costs ~10 USD per month, but there are 3 month, 6 month, 12 month, and lifetime subscriptions avaliable. I give LotRO a 10/10.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10, 2016
												First of all I want to point out that im a f2p user on this MMO, and I have by-passed many restrictions without a problem. It's an absoloutely amazing game, especially if you're a big fan of the LOTR triology, as you can easily relate to many parts in this game, story, characters etc etc...The game truly has great content, and a huge world to explore as you level up to capin at 105 :) ...Graphics are quite decent , especially on high specs, and runs quite well on alot of systems.. no matter if you have an average pc/laptop. Communities are great (from experience : primarily depending on the server activity) for the most part there is always someone there to give you a helping hand when you start off. Apart from the exciting and adventurous story and quests, LOTRO also brings PVP, which is quite competitive involving the Freeps( the good side/the classes of middle earth) vs Creeps( the monsters/evil side). Both are playable and both are great, its all up to a matter of preference which side you would like to PVP as. I wont review that in detail, but there's plenty of playthroughs and info on pvp online.Im currently a lvl 105 Beorning [ with a couple of alts of each class, all lowbies :)  ] ( totally F2p ) in the server of Evernight - Name : Hranvir, and have not spent a single cent getting her (bar VIP for 1 month, which I decided upon in the end), with expansions, and quest packs leading up as far as the end game Far Anórien quest pack (excluding the odd few quest packs/ and the helms deep expansion, which are not too necessary in reaching end game) , as well as gold cap, Auction house slots,beorning class w/ character slot , you name it. All unlocked by doing the deeds, quests etc to unlock ( LOTRO points/the in-game store currency - above the traditional gold/silver/bronze) All through arming and also using different alt characters to repeat... making hundreds each run (approximately around 400+) within 2-3 hours.It just shows that if you're a F2P even for the start, how far and how much you can achieve without paying anything, just with some time,patience and dedication, which will pay off in the end :) . Its up to you if you want to pay for the  game expansions/quest packs, especially if you feel you do not have the time at hand to farm them all out. (even going VIP for 1 month will unlock many permanent restrictions on your account (characters which you log on while VIP is up will gain benefits), aswell as giving you some TP & access to PVP as a freep, and access to all creep classes... only for the price of €13) I have done it for one month & its definitely worth it imho! Overall, if you loved the LOTR story/books/movies, and are a huge fan of MMO's ,you like open world action, the freedom to do/go as you wish, meet many new friends, and encounter some great adventures... this is the game for you! :) I personally love this game and once you get started, its quite tricky to let go :) I felt is was just really exciting, and is a great experience you might not want to miss out on :) I would certainly recommend this to anyone and you should download and give it a go right away! If you would like to have a deeper look into the game/gameplay/action and so forth, Youtube is simply the way, as it will show you through gameplay, the races/classes/mounts/ etc etc. so do check that out! LOTRO is definitely a great MMO, and one you will certainly get to grips with and enjoy! :)*This review is based from personal experiences, so to really see if it is applicable to your enjoyment, give it a go! :)  In my opinion, it is one of the best mmo games out there, and its free! *

The game give you access to many starting areas including the beloved Shire and Bree-lands as seen in the movies and books. content:
15, 2015
												I used to love this game. In fact, it was my favorite MMO. I loved the Legendary Items, loved the raids, loved the PVP, loved the crafting, and most importantly, loved the world and story. At some point along the way, Turbine suffered a few hits to their staff. Many developers were gone as a result. This was awful for the game. For some reason, they decided to take away group content and focus on "Big Battles" which some would argue that it is still group content, but it is extremely lacking. I have played this game since Shadows of Angmar beta and loved it, but without the group content and developers being let go, I have a feeling this game is dying. I hope that isn't the case. Do I recommend the game? Well, it depends. I loved what it was and hate what it's becoming. Hopefully it will get better as time goes on. Time will tell.

er 26, 2016
												This game is fun and addictive as well as free.The world is open and explorable from the moment that you finish the very helpful tutorial. The world is beautifully rendered and the art style is reminiscnt of the films. The story is also captivating as you help Gandalf and the felowship. The iconic landmarks such as Isengard, Minas Tirith and Gondor are fully Explorable and the game is completley free. No nescascary subscription, no mandatory payments only complete freedom of choice. The shop allows you to buy level boosts and other items (Weapons, Furniture, Steeds, Premium stuff, etc.) through their ingame currency, Turbine Points, and they can be earned by doing deeds. The completley free players can earn premium currency by farming and thus stay completley Free to play.8.5/10-Stefan

content:
26, 2016
												Although this game seems outdated and there are a few problems with it, I love it.Some of the strong points of the game include:  Story and lore - there is a ton of story and lore packed into this game, which is awesome if you're a Tolkien fan  Music - the music is top-notch for the most part and really fits the world well  PvE content - there is always something to do, whether it's following a quest chain to level up you or your epic weapon, following the main storyline, fighting in a skirmish, decortaing your personal or kin house, or participating in one of the many festivals  Character housing - something WoW has yet to implement...Some of the weak points of the game are:  Rewards - Turbine has a problem with giving away proper rewards in their games. It happens in their D&D game as well. you can run through a long Instance for 20 minutes and get a bit of skirmish marks, or you can do a quick skirmish and get the same number of skirmish marks. And the daily gifts are usually something you don't need or want  PvP is lacking - I'm not very much into PvP, but if you are, this probably isn't the game for you. The PvP (in LoTRO, PvMP) system seems stale and boring. It is cool to be able to fight on the monster side, though  Graphics are outdated - models and animations need to be updated, though there are many times the graphics are quite beautiful. I appreciate that the graphics are less cartoony than other MMO's, but an update would help a lotMany people complain about it now being F2P, but it doesn't bother me, I just love the LoTR world and love being part of it. This game may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I definitely recommend it for a shade of Earl Grey.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												If you are going to play it, purely F2P, you can, by grinding TP ( Turbine Points ).You can basically get the whole game that way, at the cost of several months of straight-up farming/grinding.I highly recommend that you play with other people, whether you know them or not. Playing solo is boring, as it is slow. Some classes can actually make soloing easy. However, playing solo is entirely viable. At the moment, any class can mow down tons of enemies on their own. At levels 1-90, you will hardly find anyone to play with, there isn't enough people to do stuff with, or they don't have the content, as they have to buy it.There's also a bunch of classes with their own mechanics, the most basic of them being the Guardian.If you like LOTR lore, this is for you, however, don't expect amazing end-game stuff, and don't expect a top-of-the-line story.Some may enjoy the story of LOTRO, as it ties you with the main characters from LOTR, but some may also be bored with the main stuff, rather quickly.The PVP is...meh. There isn't any structured PVP so it's all in a region called the Ettenmoors. The balance is for PVP has always been bad/awful, as there is always something OP.The community is fairly helpful compared to many other games, but there is always an occasionally jerk/idiot/whatever.If you come expecting amazing, you'll kinda feel let down. But it's good enough to say the least.                                                                 Try the game, see if you like it. It's free.

content:
, 2015
												Any fan of Lord of the Rings--casual or otherwise--will enjoy this game immensely. Every server is still highly populated (although some areas may seem barren because really, who wants to spend all day in an area that has litterally one building for miles?) and filled with people of all ages. I've met high school freshman and college graduates. The people playing this game are extremely nice and mature. I've only had two encounters with genuinely mean people and I never had to deal with them alone even if I was playing alone.There are lots of quests to do solo and lots to do in groups as little as 2 and as big as 8. There's also a mode where more than one fellowship can play together or somehing I'm pretty sure but I have yet to hit the appropriate level so I can't confirm. If none of your friends wan to play with you worry not! Most everyone is approachable and everyone has common ground. Unlike WoW or GW2 where you could start playing not knowing if you'll ever care about the lore, everyone on LOTRO likes LOTR. Some prefer the books, others prefer the movies, but you all have that common ground. There are RP servers but if you don't only want to roleplay, there are an abdundance of roleplayers running around on the normal servers to satisfy your urges when you get them.Gameplay itself is also fun. I wouldn't say it's the most outstanding thing in the entire world. You'll find similar mechanics in other MMOs and it's not any more or less engaging than those other MMOs. Depending on your class you'll get to see some really cool animations, though. The main storyline is also very engaging and very fun for fans of LOTR. I remember obsessing over it when I first started playing, haha. So yeah 10/10 I do recommend.

content:
y 16, 2016
												What can I say that hasn't already been said about Lord of the Rings Online. Released in 2007, this game has captured my attention since it was first launched with the title Shadows of Angmar. One of the last true RPGs found within the MMO genre, the game captivates with its art and design that still manages to impress nearly a decade later. Despite drawbacks in population, ownership change at Turbine (purchased by Warner Bros in 2010), and the launch of A Free-2-Play model shortly after, LOTRO still has a magical draw about it that compels players to take up arms against the Dark Lord and trek across Middle-Earth. The game is worth the subscription cost, especially if purchased for 3 or more months in advance. If unable to afford the fee, there is a Free option with limitations; just about all of which can be unlocked in-game through the use of Turbine Points gained from completing various Deeds, both kill, quest and reputation. In general, the community is helpful- much of the time willing to assist a newcomer with answers to their many questions. Give the game a try, it is perfect for the hardcore quester, casual gamer, role-player and explorer; something for just about everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
21
												I started playing LOTRO just a few weeks after it launched from Beta to full. I have to admit that I personally enjoyed the game a bit more before it switched over to Free to Play.  I didn't mind paying a subscription fee for all the hours I spent wandering through the lands I had read about for years before the game came out.  I read The Lord of the Rings many years before the movies came out and many times over at that.  I also grew up playing D&D with my friends. My friend Bill's mother was dating a guy named Dean who had played D&D since the late 70's and was an expert Dungeon Master. It was just so great to have an adult DM that put weeks and months into planning. When one of our characters died Dean actually collected the character sheet and refused to return it, their were real consequences to dying. The reason I mention all this is to point out that when I play LOTRO I'm commited to using my imagination and enjoying the game as if the books had come alive. I do not play LOTRO from the perspective of a gamer who is trying to succeed at winning a computer game. I play LOTRO as if my character is participating in Tolkiens world for real. For years I roamed around Middle Earth. I made it a habit of doing some of the things my character would do in the game. If I drank ale in the game I would drink one at home. If I grew and smoked pipeweed in the Shire I would pack a bowl and smoke weed at home. I spent years playing LOTRO extremely high. I've read that the pipeweed grown in the Shire is just tobacco, but the movie portrays it having a euphoric affect and that made more sense to me.LOTRO is really very good game. It's not perfect but it's very good.  There has been a good deal of care and detail put into this game. If you play it from a gaming perspective and just go for winning and leveling up this game's detail and Tolkien's signature depth are lost on you. When I play this game it's as if I can see where I am in my memory of Tolkiens work. People who will play this game primarily to level up and if they havent read the books or understand the locations.

												LOTRO is shaping up to be the best f2p MMO of 2017, with upcoming model/animation updates in the summer.The game is nearly 10 years old and far from dead, in fact it just found itself in the hands of a much better pubisher, Standing Stones. Community is slowly building and new content is still being released! The world is second to probably WoW in terms of exploration / lore, and gameplay is typical MMO/grindy. Think 2007. We all know the lore of Tolkien is amazing, and the game pays really good attention to the books, so I've heard.Basically, if you've tried more modern MMOs and they aren't your thing you might be looking for more immersion or depth, and LOTRO can give you that (for free)! You can purchase expansions for the game, which by the time you get to I'm assuming you'd be willing to pay for them. Get them on sale when you can.

content:
14, 2015
												This is definitely my favourite MMO that I have played to date. I have played it before getting Steam, so I have way more game time than it actually shows.This game is basically WOW, except less limited in the free to play. You can unlock everything in the game just in F2P, and there is no difference, except for a few perks, between a player who is F2P or not. There is one location that requires you to be VIP : a location for Player vs Monster Player fighting, but there is another location for that.The graphics are not disappointing, considering this game was initially released in 2009, but could use an upgrade to bring them to modern level.Speaking of updates, these are happening constantly, with bug fixes, but also new areas and locations, quests, and other content. Now for the quests. Well, to be completely honest with you, while the main epic quest is loads of fun, and actually had me engrossed in the story for quite some time, (It's really good !), the intro quest for the Elf start is.... lacking. Sure the beginning of it is, kind of awesome, in the middle it is just pure boredom. I had to spend several different day doing it, simply because I was bored with the walking - talking - walking - fetch item - walking quests. That would literally be nearly half of the quests in the tutorial, which takes an HOUR to complete. That being said, the end of the Elf tutorial picks up the pace once again, but - not really that great.Combat is absolutely fine, no issues with the abilities of any kind, Hunters' focus system is to be enjoyed with the balance. Different combinations of the abilities can be used to fight different monsters and also people. There is a PvP system - you can spar outside of major cities.The map is just spectacular. You can explore the entirety of Middle-Earth, with different regions corresponding to different skill levels so you always have something to do in the game.Overall - 8/10, really fun game, but a few of the quests are boring and repetitive, with a few bugs.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
21, 2015
												A long-enduring ever-expansive homage to the alternative history that is Middle-Earth, that will absolutely bury you in its many miniature gameplay mechanics steadily accumulated and tweaked over its now 8-year-long course.  And while it my look like an overwhelming ammount of content to go through to a new player, the fact that this game is most proud of is, be you a level 1, 30, 50 or 100, there always seems plenty to do to feel rewarding, and a time well spent. Mechanically, its a by-the-numbers MMORPG game, very much entrenched into evey known trope of an early 21st century online game. But its style and gameplay hasn't yet been hampered by it, rather built around it. There's the standard 50+ skillbar of each fairly ballanced class which compliment eachother in a D&D kind of way (the tanky one, the squishy dps one, the buffer, the healer, the run-around-do-whatever-you-like one), working together without ironic subtext, since Tolkien basically wrote the book on them  (ugh...) inadvertently defined the classical dungeon crawling class system anyway. You TAB around the monsters presented and diminish their red bars. Alternatively, you gather materials, craft, randomly explore, complete numerous deeds, roleplay (it is, obviously, an extremely RP frienldy game), buy junk, sell junk, play through story mode, pvmp, do instances (scalable) do quests, do quests, do quests........The strongest parts are indeed the stories of numerouns inhabitants of the world, gated behind and propelled by your typical fetch and kill x quests. You could do a lot worse then reading through abysmal ammount of text walls of these chatty NPC's, and, if you're a fan of the setting, it will be a treat throughout the game. It is skippable of course, but this is a text heavy game.The FTP model can safely get you through 1-50 without much hassle, and the remaining content is gated behind purchases, but, by then, you'll already decide if its worth your money and time. As stated above, there's plenty to do in Eriador anyway, before venturing forth through Moria into Rhovanion, Rohan and Gondor.Tip: Get a mount as soon as you can, it's a massive game. And don't venture into Prancing Pony drunk. Oh yeah, grinding is, for the most part, optional.Highly reccomended.

												I have good memories of this game, the environment is massive and detailed (although don't expect next gen graphics, it's a 8 year old game). The main questline is fun, and although the side quests can be a little grind-y, they are easily done without much effort as you complete the main storylines.But the main reason that I loved this game is just exploring the world of the Lord of the Rings. Whether you want to go to Hobbiton or Bree, or into Lothlorien, Moria, or now even Minas Tirith and Helm's Deep there's so much to see and do. You can join a kinship and make new friends there and just immerse yourself in the world.

content:
ber 19, 2015
												All the reviews below pretty much sum up how I feel about Lord of the Rings Online. I just felt the need to mention one feature that no one else mentioned, and that I feel makes LOTRO unique like no other MMO- the player music system. You can equip a musical instrument in game and, either by hitting keys or launching an ABC music file, play a song in game that people in the area can hear. Players have formed bands that give concerts, and on Landroval server there is even a yearly event called Weatherstock that attracts musicians from many servers for a day of music on Weathertop. Even if you don't roleplay, the abilty to perform and listen to player music in game adds so much to the experience.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												So, I've been playing this game off and on for the last four and a half years, so I would say I've seen enough of it to write an hoenst review. What I love most about the game are the story and the immersion you feel when you're playing. You really feel like you're a part of the Middle Earth World, which to me means a lot (I'm obssessed with Lord of the Rings). The regions are varied enough that you feel like every place is different. Also, each class has its own unique characteristics that set it apart from the other classes; most people have multiple characters on multiple servors because they want to capitalize on all the different class options and play styles.The main problems I have with LOTRO are that the combat is getting clunky, certain classes are way overpowered compared to others, and the questing in certain regions is getting a bit monotonous. The combat is generally the same the whole game, so it's important that you pick the class that goes with what you want in the game. It can just be very repetitive at times. Likewise, certain classes are way stronger than other classes. My hunter is so frail at level 89 compared to most other classes. So frail that it becomes difficult to get through basic solo quests. Finally, the quest are around the same thing over and over again. I know there can only be a finite number of quest ideas, but I would appreciate more diversity in questing. Overall, I find myself coming back to this game every couple of months, getting bored, and then coming back again in a cycle. I've done this for four years now, and I expect to d othe same for at least a couple more years. 8.5/10

content:
er 3, 2015
												I have good memories of this game, the environment is massive and detailed (although don't expect next gen graphics, it's a 8 year old game). The main questline is fun, and although the side quests can be a little grind-y, they are easily done without much effort as you complete the main storylines.But the main reason that I loved this game is just exploring the world of the Lord of the Rings. Whether you want to go to Hobbiton or Bree, or into Lothlorien, Moria, or now even Minas Tirith and Helm's Deep there's so much to see and do. You can join a kinship and make new friends there and just immerse yourself in the world.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
r 23, 2015
												If you're looking for a world where the soul is in the heartfelt community rather than flash-in-the-pan, technological gimmicks, look no further than this version of Middle Earth. Come, explore, make some friends, relax, and be fulfilled by the best kind of 'leveling' & 'progress', the kind that involves no stats nor scores. The kind that involves spending the whole day fishing and talking with friends, perhaps serenading a random audience in the town square with a song that you literally wrote, or having a snowball fight in Winter, or even racing through a corn maze in Fall. Sure you could get to max level if you want, but this is a world where the person with the best attitude wins, not the one with the highest level, thanks to the best MMORPG community I've ever seen.

content:
er 26, 2013
												If you're a RolePlayer this is almost a must-try MMORPG. LotRo has one of the best RP communities on it's Landroval server that you will find pretty much anywhere. Fairly standard combat for an MMO, but the Rohan expansion adds quite a bit of flare to that. You won't find better in terms of lore, immersion, and a die hard tolkein fan base.The game's one downfall in my opinion is the free-to-play model that is currently in place. You will be spending a lot of time re-rolling characters and running the same zones over and over to earn enough points to unlock the next quest packs, expansions, bag upgrades etc.. etc.. My recommendation is to subscribe and get everything for a monthly fee, minus the expansions that will have to be purchased of course.

content:
4
												Maybe im just getting too old and don't have the patience of old. Big fan of lotr, and mmos. Couldn't believe this game was free, i remember thinking "wow how could i have missed this gem" especially after reading the great reviews this game got. This game reminded me a bit of Warhammer Online which was an mmo i loved so much. The only reason this game has survived this long is because of lotr fans. There is a decent "fanatic" playerbase that won't let this game die and they need newbies to come along to feed and boost their ego. I dont mind that aspect, i was that player in Warhammer online. But what made me uninstall this game was the fact that you have to PAY to get ahead for everything... and i mean EVERYTHING. Every quest every notification you get is "Go to the LOTRO store to unlock this" or "Go to the LOTRO store to make this faster" its absurd how none of the reviews i read mentioned this. probably because i only focused on the good. I get how the devs need to make money but come on! at one point i thought "well, im an adult with a job and its a free game... why not spend a little cash" so i took a look at the lotro store and i was shocked! VIP for a year is like 200 dollars! if i want to buy a simple horse to get around 25 dollars! everything is so expensive and this game is sooooo old! i think the graphics on Zelda on the N64 looked 10x better! The quests consists of : talk to Sally Took, now talk to Barbara Took, now go back to Sally to tell her what Barbara said, now go back to Barbara to tell her of Sally's response.... And they're 10 minutes apart!!!  (without buying the 25 dollar horse) im sure this game will get better if i were to put more hours into it, but i can already tell i would have to spend a significant amount of money to compete, and to make it worthwhile. I like being rewarded for having no life and grind out levels/items... i don't like being rewarded for how much cash i have to spend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 30, 2016
												So, Lord of the Rings Online is fairly good MMORPG here with a couple of nuances:1. This is a game about the lore for the Tolkien's writing. Tolkiens fans can start with it all fine, all others would need some time to understand what is, actually, up in here. Let's say you didn't read the books, but you do want to start your sinking in it with a game? Then LotRO is definitely your bet.2. This isn't a game about PvP. While there are friendly duels and PMvP (Player-controlled Monsters versus Player) raids this isn't a focus for the project, neither it's really entertaining. Enjoyed being a ravaging orc for a change though.3. This game isn't about wiggling breasts, like, at all (notably other games on the market are, like TERA or Black Desert Online). Personally I like this aspect of the game second to lore, so if you're after storytelling and not the boobs you'll do fine.4. This game has a ton of cooperational group content to do from the very start of the game (lvls 20+), both very interesting and entertaining. Consider to make friends in kinship (local name for clans) or invite your own friends!5. This game requires some reading skills. I mean, quest texts are really good, and some of the side quest stories are awesome to the marvelous point.6. This game is great for exploring. The more areas you explore 'to the last tree out there', the more stories to hear/read you uncover, the more rewarding the deed system goes on you (deeds are in-game achievements you get tons of premium currency for). 7. Payment system isn't that unfriendly to free players if you ask me. Yes, grinding premium currency with deeds can be tiresome if you buy nothing, but hey!.. Get Steam packs available for the game and you'll do just fine. 15 USD (when on sale) and you won't need to buy anything else in months.These developers deserve support with our hard-earned cash.8. While some point out that the graphics of the game are outdated I can't call those 'ugly'. I'd say older locations look like the Gothic II ones (which isn't bad, you know) while new ones can be stunningly beatiful. Visit Evendim peaks and Forochel coasts to see what I mean.9. Music puts Peter Jackson to shame, really. Definitely a strong side for the game.10. And the last, but not the least thing about the game is the Community. People come and go, but old players always return to LotRO, so you can find all types of people in. Seasoned veterans, who played the game for 8 years, new lads and lasses, some experienced folk to group with... Roleplayers, that enjoy the very social aspects for the game. You'll certainly fit in our bunch :)Total score would be 9\10 points for the people that share the same things to love with me and 3/10 for the people that just want running around a half-naked curvy girl with a sword larger than the girl.

												I may only have played this game 7 hours (as of writing this review). But those 7 hours was enough to make this my new favorite-game! This has to be the most beautiful game of all time (I dont mean the graphics). The gameplay, the world and everthing else (except the graphics) is fantastic! If you are a big Tolkien-fan, like my-self. This is the game you have been looking for! PROS:+ Fantastic gameplay+ The best open world ever. You can explore almost all of middle-earth (if not all, I dont really know)!+ If you are a fan of the books or the movies, this is the game for you!+ Personally, I think this is the best recreation of Tolkiens fantastic world.+ You can meet the Dwarves from The Hobbit.+ Fantastic in everyway+ My new favourite-game+ The soundtrack is fantastic+ There is only two bad things about the game (that I have seen)+ You can play as a Hobbit, Dwarf, Man, Elf and Beorning.+ The story is great!CONS:- The graphics isnt the best.- You can only have two characters/server if you dont buy another characterslot.10/10 best game of all time!

content:
ry 2, 2016
												Ahhh,LOTRo where to begin.This game is honestly the best classic tab targeting MMO i have ever played.Before i tell why i think so i will first tell you the cons of this game as to get them out of the way.1.Its a bit old so the graphics are not as good as modern games,still pleasent graphics(its not virtua fighter)just not as nice as shiny new games2.Its new content is made under a differant company then old LOTRO so it feels a bit differant,not bad just differant.3.Long travel times between destinations.This is commonplace in MMOs but LOTRO is big and fast travel is limited so yeah,lots of running around.This is easily mitigated by LOTROs excellent vistas and the steam overview if you wanna browse the store or something while traveling,or just talk in chat.PROS!!!1.Firstly and most important is that LOTROs community is by far the best in any game.This fact is so true as to almost be undebatable.Every person i have ever met in this game was great.2.This is lord of the rings,so you instantly have the greatest fantasy world and lore ever created to explore and adventure in.3.Varied classes.You start with some good class staples like Guardian and Hunter,but some really special ones are included like warden(a combo based tank in a tab targeting game?Its crazy fun for more skill based play.Runekeeper(super adaptible healer/dps)and countless other cool stuff about the other classes.4.The world building is close to perfect for a classic (but fresh) take on the lord of the rings.In conclusion i love this this game and while you may not,you have to try it,at least two very differant classes to lvl 30,and make friends!these people are great they make f2ps and newbies right at home.GO PLAY IT!

content:
2, 2016
												So, I've played through the intro of this game and done a bit of free roaming with my friend, so I thought I'd give some first impressions. (The Quest Log section may be updated, so you may want to check back at some point if you're interested, which I expect you aren't).PLOT:Judging by the intro and the dream sequence at level 5, your character (my first one being the Hobbit Burgular, Mimbulius) is the chosen one (or something like that) whose destiny is tied to the fate of Middle-Earth! The story is set out in quests that vary depending on which character you are (my friend was a dwarf and met Gandalf and Thorin and all the other dwarves from The Hobbit while I was just helping out around this little village that got attacked for five minutes).GAMEPLAY:Open World, quest-based gameplay. It is very much like World of Warcraft, but it's still a good MMO. QUEST LOG:Day 1: My friend and I set out from Erebor on the free horses they give you for 24 hours after completing the intro, and we decided that we were going to go from Erebor to Mordor, stopping at certain locations to look around. We rode to Hobbiton, where we found Bag End and looked around, then we headed off into the Bree-Lands to find The Inn of the Prancing Pony. My friend thought he could take on a bear, and it chased us all the way into Bree. At the Pony, I got my haircut and got drunk, while my friend sold all his junk items to Barliman Butterbur. We then set off for Weathertop, as my friend did not want to stay the night in Bree as to be safe. Weathertop is in the Lone Lands, what we now know to be as quite a dangerous place for two Level Sixes to be riding through at night. My friend was lucky and actually managed to make it onto the ruins, but I, however, was attacked by some freaking ravens! Meanwhile, my friend wasn't having the best time up on the hill, and he managed to use some magical item or something to teleport back to Erebor. It was just me now, so I rode on, past Weathertop, to try and go through the Trollshaws to Rivendell...I was killed two minutes later, and used my instant respawn, only to be killed again about twenty seconds after. I then respawned at a safe place (the entrance to the Lone Lands) as day began. My ride through the Lone Lands was fine, and nothing attacked me at all. If only my friend had actually listened when I suggested waiting in Bree until morning. I entered the Trollshaws, and the game warned me that this area was Level 30, but I was determined. I rode through the Trollshaws, with monsters chasing me. I reached the river that seperates the Trollshaws from Rivendell, and rode on. I could not see a path to Rivendell, so I rode up a hill to get a better view. At this point, I stopped, and, as I checked the map, the monsters caught up with me and attacked me. I moved away from the monsters, and they chased me. I moved back again, forgetting a crucial detail - I was on the edge of a hill. I fell 200ft, still riding my horse, and died as my body smashed into the same river I had believed to be the end of my worries. I had to use a 'Safe Respawn' that took me to the middle of a place called Archet, on the borders of Bree. I left to go and play Town of Salem instead.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 5, 2014
												I've played this game for ages (since 2009). Thousands of hours more than Steam will show. It has been a long running favorite with huge amounts of space to explore and a skirmish system that other MMOs need to pay attention to.The downside is the game is starting to show its age a bit more than WoW does. The art in the game manages to land square in the uncanny valley and the player animation is sloppy. Anyone with a speed buff comically trots in place when starting or stopping. No ability to unsheath weapons, and everyone in your party will be synchronized when entering or exting combat. These things are minor, but jarring. Hunter's port system has become a chore, and travel from point to point to point is now confusing and tedious. Travel needs to be revamped to just a drop down of where you want to go at this point. Also, a lot of this game is simply NIH going extra lengths to not be WoW even when WoW-like was the right thing to do.The upside is the game continuously expands and improves. New gameplay mechanics, often new innovations, are introduced with each year. The lore is immersive (as it should be), and elaboration happens with consent and approval from the Tolkien estate. The cosmetic outfit system is an example of a place where WoW (and every other MMO) specifically needs to take notice. Content is often truely difficult rather than outright unfair, even when playing retro-content several levels under you.Warsteeds were a fizzle addition to the game, largely because they amplified the slop in the controls by an intentionally sloppy and unweidly system. PvMP (because WoW calls it PvP) is amazing, but often unbalanced as stats start in favor of monsters and end in favor of Hobbits by the end of an xpac cycle. Legendary weapons are not cosmetically customizable and obsoleted every xpac. This flys in the face of the intent of the original intent of the system, and is a very tedious grind. The legendary system is also confusing and dependant on huge amounts of randomness. Keep these as your forwarning as they will be the biggest sore points.Despite the complaints here, I still love this game. I still recommend this game. I hope that they will approach fixing the sloppy controls and simplify the legendary system as these are the only things causing me to drift towards other games.

4, 2016
												Overall I love this game and would recommend it to anyone. What I like about this game is that there are a lot of things to do from customizing your character, weapons, clothing, housing all of it. There are lots of quest too some some of which are repeatable. You even get to pick a trade like woodworking or being a scholar just to name a few. You can join a kinship or start one of your own and help eachother out. You also get to interact with the original characters from Middle Earth like Gandalf, Aragorn, Legolas, Frodo, and so many others. The one thing I think is a drawback is that you have to spend money to unlock most reigons in order to be able to do quest in them and there are some other items such as mounts and clothing that you need to buy with money as well. And there is a gold cap so you have to pay to expand that as well. So unless you have a job, or some deep pockets you can dig into and if you're not a giant passionionate fan for Lord of the Rings then this game is mostlikey not for you. But if the above is not an issue for you then I would totally say this is a great game for you. :)

content:
er 26, 2014
												Lord of the Rings Online or (LORTO) is several years old at this point (2007) but it's probably still the best theme based MMO in the genre. The character models are a bit date but the landscapes are gorgeous, the combat is at times slow and predictable, however, Turbine has made great strides in trying to improve the game "play speed". To really understand LOTRO you must understand the reason people play this MMO.1) The Story - Plain and simple people play this game for the lore surrounding it more than any other factor.2) The Community - The people who play this game are by far the most mature and helpful community of MMO players that I have ever seen. This has fallen away somewhat with the addition of a FTP model some years ago and the recent addition of a Global Chat Channel3) The casual nature and pacing of this game. Everything about LOTRO is tailored toward a more mature type of MMO gamer, So much so before the last major exspansion Turbine just flatly said that there will not be creating any more raid or large group content since no one does it anyway.A lot of people may or may not agree with this review but I really tried to distill why the people who play this game play it. If you find yourself drifting in the see of MMOs out there and just want to log in and deliver some pies in the Shire or See the Long Dark of Moria this just may be the game for you.

content:
2, 2014
												To properly appreciate this game, you need to invest a fair amount of time into. I would say the game itself is a fairly standard RPG, perhaps above average for a free to play and it doesn't bog you down in restricted VIP only areas. However, a big selling point for me was the fact it was LOTR and I got to explore all the places I wanted to visit from the films. This was FRIGGIN AWESOME. I admit, I spent the majority of this game playing with friends, so I cannot vouch for the solo experience but questing together was the most fun I had on an MMORPG.Throughout the game, you may be able to save up enough currency to never need to invest actual money into it, however I bought the mithril starter pack which gave me enough points to progress as far as I wanted. The first purchase you need to save for is buying a horse to actually be able to get around. This is relatively painless and involves completing a fair few early tasks to get the points. Apart from that advice, take your sword, your bow and your axe and go out and explore the world of MiddleEarth!

content:
er 25, 2016
												My gametime lies, I played this for over 2 years through HappyCloud before I started playing it through Steam instead ;)This game is highly underrated in my opinion, and although it's an older game it still has a lot going for it.  The pros:  - Tolkien lore, sooo much Tolkien lore.  - Ever wanted to get drunk in the Prancing Pony? Now you can.  - Great community for an MMO, trolls seem few, people are friendly, player-run events a-plenty.  - The in game music system.  You can use lore-friendly musical instruments in game to play ABC files of your favourite music, and even sync with other people in your party to form a band & play the same songs in time on different instruments.  - The free-to-play model allows for a pretty lengthy free trial period.  After that you'll want to become VIP (a subscriber) to enjoy the rest of the game, HOWEVER you only need to go VIP once to unlock everything, and it all stays unlocked if you cancel your subscription, so it's not necessary to keep paying.- Huge list of Instances, Skirmishes & Epic Battles to participate in.- Player owned houses, and Kinship (Guild) houses which are all customizeable.  - Wardrobe feature allows for lots of outfit customization.- Monster play feature allows for PvP battles while sticking to Tolkien lore.  - Extensive crafting system, & auctions of course.Cons: - Graphics are showing their age, certainly not an ugly game, but not the stunning graphics we're getting used to seeing either.- Standard MMORPG mechanics.  Nothing particularly new or exciting in terms of gameplay, basically just another WoW clone, but with Tolkien lore.- Free-to-play is limited, you will need to spend some money to enjoy the rest of the game.If you're a fan of Tolkien lore then definitely give it a try, if you're not, then there's propably much better MMO's out there for you to try instead.  This game does stock-standard MMORPG pretty well, but it's main draw point is definitely the setting & lore.

content:
ry 22
												If you're a Tolkien fan, you should love this. It's a lot of fun seeing how much care and attention has gone into recreating the world of middle earth. As an MMO, it is one of the best ones out. It is certainly more geared to solo players, but does a good job of catering to everyone. The classes range from basic to some of the most advanced and interesting classes I've ever seen in an MMO. (Take Warden or LoreMaster for example)! The community is also one of the friendliest and the servers are still busy and alive to this day. It has stood the test of time and still looks astonishingly beautiful as ever. Add to all that it has fantastic mood setting music you've got a class A product. Many players simply can't stop at a single character and over the years I have kept on coming back to this game. Without a doubt my favourite MMO ever. It's also great to see the dedication of Standing Stone in keeping their work alive and keeping lotro safe for the future years with a decent, not overly greedy free to play system. Much of the content can be enjoyed for free and extras can be bought as required. The only time you may consider spending money is to open up quest packs in different regions and expansion packs. But considering the size and amount of time you could foreseeably spend in this masterpiece, it is well worth it!

content:
8, 2014
												This was one of my first MMOs and I am so happy it was. The combat and graphics may seem a little outdated but it is still fun beyond belief. It's not easy but it's not too challenging, it's super fun to play with your friends, the map is GIANT and there's so much to see and do. Within my first few days of playing I was invited to a guild by very nice players who taught me everything and showed me how to play, I progressed slowly until I was a total bad ♥♥♥, I spent hours looking for the correct ores to make the best weapons and armor possible. The gameplay is perfect. You start out by fighting wolves with a weak short sword and leather armor and a few days later you'll be taking on orcs and giants with your friends and dual wielding swords that took hours to make and heavy steel armor. THe progression is quite slow which personally I love. But that may bother some people. You can do epic boss fights and raids to earn special money that you can spend at camps to get weapons and armor that look like they were crafted by the gods. This game is also truly free to play. If you want to spend real money on special coins go ahead but it's definitely not forced upon you. You can do everything without spending a dime. I played this game all spring break with my friend. It doesn't matter if you have an old mac and a poor mouse. I spent the majority of this game on a mac and a poor mouse and it ran perfectly. This game may not look like it but if you put the time and effort into it, it will blow your mind. If you can get over mediocre graphics and sorta outdated combat then trust me you'll love this. Anyone who appreciates a good MMO will absolutely LOVE this game!

content:
r 5, 2014
												I've played this game for ages (since 2009). Thousands of hours more than Steam will show. It has been a long running favorite with huge amounts of space to explore and a skirmish system that other MMOs need to pay attention to.The downside is the game is starting to show its age a bit more than WoW does. The art in the game manages to land square in the uncanny valley and the player animation is sloppy. Anyone with a speed buff comically trots in place when starting or stopping. No ability to unsheath weapons, and everyone in your party will be synchronized when entering or exting combat. These things are minor, but jarring. Hunter's port system has become a chore, and travel from point to point to point is now confusing and tedious. Travel needs to be revamped to just a drop down of where you want to go at this point. Also, a lot of this game is simply NIH going extra lengths to not be WoW even when WoW-like was the right thing to do.The upside is the game continuously expands and improves. New gameplay mechanics, often new innovations, are introduced with each year. The lore is immersive (as it should be), and elaboration happens with consent and approval from the Tolkien estate. The cosmetic outfit system is an example of a place where WoW (and every other MMO) specifically needs to take notice. Content is often truely difficult rather than outright unfair, even when playing retro-content several levels under you.Warsteeds were a fizzle addition to the game, largely because they amplified the slop in the controls by an intentionally sloppy and unweidly system. PvMP (because WoW calls it PvP) is amazing, but often unbalanced as stats start in favor of monsters and end in favor of Hobbits by the end of an xpac cycle. Legendary weapons are not cosmetically customizable and obsoleted every xpac. This flys in the face of the intent of the original intent of the system, and is a very tedious grind. The legendary system is also confusing and dependant on huge amounts of randomness. Keep these as your forwarning as they will be the biggest sore points.Despite the complaints here, I still love this game. I still recommend this game. I hope that they will approach fixing the sloppy controls and simplify the legendary system as these are the only things causing me to drift towards other games.

												As you can see i have alot of houres on record. This game is free to play and you can run around the entire world but to be able to do quests you will need to buy them. you buy them with turbine points. these points are also gained by completing deeds. So in fact if you want you could play this game completely for free but it just takes longer. I personaly realy like the game because of the realy big world and the manny possibilities you have withing the game.first off when starting you have 5 differend races to choose of and within those races manny differend classes (some don't work with some races). a few you have to buy with TP. there are 4 differend starting stories that help you to get to know the game. one of the big things on the side is crafting. you can make annything. in the differend areas are differend recourses.the grafics are not top notch but for such a huge game it is fantastic and if you have all the grafic setings maxed out you can find some realy nice vieuws. The social aspect of the game is realy important for manny quests are hard to impossible to complete on your own. thanks to the fellowships this can be done. And a mayor part of the time you will find yourself playing in a kinship. I met some amazing people from all over the world, some youngh some old (ranging 15-65) but all amazing in their own way.the game does allow in game voice chat but the quality isn't so superb.i personly love this game, the most time i ever put into one game. almost at 2000 houres.
